loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a hardworking man. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. He is a happy man.

He sells firewood at retail prices to his customers. He has been in this business for a long time. He works for long hours to ensure that there is food on their table to feed his family. He is married with four children and he is 48 years old. His eldest child is 23 years old.

He is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more firewood to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Wycliff

texts.en: Wycliff is 35 years old and married with a two-year-old daughter store and sells vegetables, onions, cereals and potatoes to walk-ins and local residents  He owns the Benta Groceries dents. He has been in this business for the last six years.  His business challenges are strong competition from similar business and decreased demand from his customers due to their low incomes.  He is using the loan of 50,000 KES to buy cereals, onions, potatoes, fruits and vegetables.  He is looking forward to becoming the major distributor of foodstuff in his area.  Wycliff describes himself as ambitious, social and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy cereals, onions, potatoes, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther sells drinks at the main market in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She is 55 years old and married with eight children. Even at her age, she still puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

She hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell and believes this will expand her business and give her family a better living. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is thirty seven years old and married with four children. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits etc. in the local market.

She wants to use this loan to buy a bulk supply of rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted food spices, washing soaps and powders to expand her business. Victoria hopes to make good income from the expanded business to enable her provide the children with quality education.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries in bulk.

loans.name: Faizullo

texts.en:
F. Faizullo is a 32 year old man who raises cows and sells dairy products to local people and factories. He is married and has two children. Since he grew up in a farming family, Faizullo has learned how to raise, breed, and sell dairy cows and other livestock. Faizullo would like to expand his business and purchase additional cows and fodder for TJS4000. The purpose is to expand his business and improve the life of his family. Faizullo has been working very hard for this aim and hopes that his loan will help him and make his financial income more stable.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Esperanza Group

texts.en: This committee was formed in Caaguazú, when Emerita Quiñonez invited a group of women to come together when she learned about the Women’s Entrepreneurship program. She gathered 17 women, all of whom were enthusiastic about working together to take out a loan to improve their businesses. All of the women already had jobs, as venders of clothing, shoes, jewelry, fruits and vegetables. They decided to use their loan to invest further in their businesses, and received between PYG1,200,000 and PYG300,000 each depending on the size of their business. They used their loans to buy sugar, meat, flour, eggs, noodles, cheese, candy, and clothing, including jeans, shirts, skirts, lingerie. They share a common goal to improve their businesses and their lives, for themselves and for their families.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Rachel Florentine

texts.fr: A. Rachel Florentine est née vers 1975 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Mariée à SOSSOU Germain un conducteur de taxi moto, Rachel Florentine est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Rachel Florentine vit avec ses enfants à Ahito à Allada, depuis près de 7 ans.  Rachel Florentine supporte seule les charges de la famille. Rachel Florentine a fait seulement le cours primaire à l'école. Depuis environs 5 ans, Rachel Florentine vend de la nourriture (come, nourriture traditionnelle faite à base de maïs, accompagnée de sauce) à Allada. A côté de cette activité, Rachel Florentine vend également des tissus par le système de distribution. Rachel Florentine s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. C'est en vue d'accroître son activité et donc de préparer et de vendre davantage son repas par jour, que Rachel Florentine sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Rachel Florentine was born in 1975 in Allada, in the county of Atlantique in Bénin. Rachel Florentine is married to Sossou Germain, a motorcycle taxi conductor. They have 5 children, some of whom are currently attending school. Rachel Florentine has lived with her children in Ahito, within Allada, for the past 7 years. Rachel Florentine carries the load of her family alone. Rachel Florentine only attended primary school. For the past 5 years, Rachel Florentine has sold foodstuffs ("come", a traditional corn-based food, accompanied with sauce) in Allada. In addition to this, Rachel Florentine also sells fabrics through her distribution system. Rachel Florentine supplies herself in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Rachel Florentine is an old client of ALIDé, who has already benefitted from three loans from ALIDé, these loans have all been fully repaid. In order to grow her business, and therefore to prepare and sell more meals everyday, Rachel Florentine is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of corn and sauces (tomato, onion, spicy, etc.)

loans.name: Maruf

texts.en:
I. Maruf is a 45 year old man who is the loving father of two adorable children. Maruf works very hard to cover all the needs of his children. He has been selling livestock and dairy products together with his wife as a primary business since 1999. He provides the markets with meat and his family with the necessary food. At the same time, he cultivates different kinds of vegetables on his land. Maruf wants to buy young cattle and fertilizer for his land and therefore he is requesting a loan of TJS4000. He wants to earn more income so he can provide his children with a good education and improve their lives. This amount would help him accomplish his goals in a short time. Be an important part of the growth of Maruf’s business.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle and fertilizer for his land.

loans.name: Abdufatto

texts.en:
Abdufatto B. is 65 years old and lives with his wife and two children. He is a hard-working person, which he demonstrates each and every day as he carries out the arduous tasks of living in the countryside. Abdufatto has been a farmer from the start, having inherited his lands – and the occupation – from his parents. With the passing of time, he has also implemented raising livestock into his enterprise. Each day, he takes his cows to graze in the far reaches of his fields. With these activities, he earns income to support the living expenses of his family. Abdufatto is learning every day how to run his business to the best end result. He seeks a loan for working capital, specifically so he can buy cattle, considering that the prices for them are low now. Abdufatto deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is a 45 year old trader. She is married and has three children who are currently in school. She sells used clothing and has been in this business for the past 10 years. With low capital, she is not able to buy larger quantities of used clothes to sell. Therefore she is requesting a loan to buy a larger variety of used clothing in order to increase her stock. She hopes to use part of her proceeds to support her children’s education. She desires to expand her business and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase assorted used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Abdusattor

texts.en:
Abdusattor K., married with two adult children, has been raising cattle since 1983 with his wife (pictured). At the end of 2007 he found out about the microloan fund of IMON, and since then has been working with IMON, showing himself to be a reliable client. Now Abdusattor needs a new loan to expand his business in order to increase his profits. He lives in a village and has no problem feeding additional animals. In the future, Abdusattor plans to expand into milk processing business. With your help, he can achieve all of his goals.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. loans.use: Purchasing of calves to expand the business

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: Leticia is thirty-four years old. She is married with two children who are currently in school. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, washing powder, toilet cleaner, candies, and biscuits in the local market of her community. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk supplies of items including rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, assorted food spices, and washing soaps and powders to expand her business. Leticia hopes to make a good income from the expanded business to help her to take care of her children, including their school fees.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries in bulk

loans.name: Khairullo

texts.en:
Khairullo is 25 years old, and he lives with his wife and two children. He is a livestock breeder. He has been doing this for the past 6 years and considers it very profitable. Khairullo takes his livestock to the pastures every morning for their nourishment. Then, after caring for them for several months, he takes them to be sold. But this phase is complicated due to transportation issues. Because he does not own his own vehicle, he must work within the schedules and prices that are offered to him. He also sporadically ventures into agriculture, but he does not do this full-time because he believes that times have changed considerably and it is no longer a satisfactory occupation.

Khairullo’s two children are his reason for continuing his efforts as a livestock breeder and farmer. Currently he needs a loan of 3,500 somoni to expand his business. Your support can help improve the quality of life for Khairullo and his family and help their business grow and prosper. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of calves to expand the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries in bulk

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy is married with 4 children and she is 43 years old. All her children are doing well in school. She is a member of the Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) microfinance institution. She sells drinks opposite her house in Warri to earn money. She is very hardworking and she makes sure she has food on the table every day through her hard work. She has requested a loan amounting to 50,000 Nigerian naira, which she intends to use in buying drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Angéline Thérèse Afiavi

texts.fr: A. Angéline Thérèse Afiavi est née le 02 Octobre 1964 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Angéline Thérèse Afiavi réside à Ahito à Allada depuis près de 46 ans. Mariée à HOUNKPONOU Richard, Angéline Thérèse Afiavi est mère de sept enfants, tous scolarisés, dont cinq sont à sa charge. Angéline Thérèse Afiavi vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Angéline Thérèse Afiavi a fait seulement le cours primaire. Depuis près de 30 ans, Angéline Thérèse Afiavi vend de la nourriture (riz, pâte de maïs, pâte faite à base de cossette d'igname, accompagnés de sauce). Angéline Thérèse Afiavi mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de boissons à Allada. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin que Angéline Thérèse Afiavi s'approvisionne. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. En vue d'accroître le volume de ses produits et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Angéline Thérèse Afiavi sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Angéline Thérèse Afiavi was born on October 2, 1964 in Allada, in Atlantique county. She has been residing in Ahito, in Allada, for nearly 46 years. Married to HOUNKPONOU Richard, she is the mother of seven children who are all in school. Five of them are in her care. She lives together with her children and husband. The couple provides for the family jointly. Angéline Thérèse Afiavi has gone to primary school only. For nearly thirty years, she has been selling food (rice, mash made from cormeal, and mash made from yam chips , all served with a sauce). She runs a secondary business selling drinks in Allada. She stocks up in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client who repays her loans. With the aim of increasing the volume of her goods and to satisfy customer demand further, she’s requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of yam chips, corn, and rice

loans.name: Estela

texts.en:
Estela P. is 33 years old and has been married to Ever Cristaldo, who is 37 years old, for 14 years. They have two sons, 16 and 8 years old, both of whom are in school.

Estela started her business 4 years ago with a small amount of capital that her husband gave her, which he had saved up from his business in manufacturing furniture. Estela began to buy used clothes and re-sell them, and now has a clothing shop.

She wants her business to keep growing, and to increase her income. Her dream is to allow her children to go to university and grow up to be successful and well educated. She will use this loan to buy pants, shorts, shoes, blouses, children’s clothes, shirts, and shoes, in order to increase the variety in her store and satisfy her customers' demand.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Shew

texts.en:
Shew A. is 48 years old and married with 6 children. His youngest child is 19 years old. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria.

Shew is a focused, hard worker. He sells bags of maize and groundnuts. He has been in this business for a long time. His greatest joy in his business is the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers.

Shew is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more bags of maize to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize to sell.

loans.name: Abdramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdramane  Traoré  est âgé de 34 ans marié et père de quatre enfants. Il est domicilié  avec sa femme et ses enfants dans la quartier Banconi–Koulikoro, région de Sikasso.
Abdramane après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initié à l’ activité d'achat- stockage et commercialisation des céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho) il y a maintenant sept  ans. Il dispose d’un magasin à Kaboïla I en face de la clinique médicale Guinso. Il est très sollicité.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte acheter, 23 sacs de maïs et 23 sacs de mil en provenance des localités environnantes de Sikasso. Ces marchandises sont d’abord stockées dans son magasin afin d’êtres revendues en gros à une clientèle composée des détaillants et des chefs de famille.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdramane Traoré, 34, is married and the father of 4 children. He lives with his wife and his children in the Banconi–Koulikoro district, Sikasso region. Abdramane, after having tried out a number of businesses with no success, began buying, warehousing, and selling cereals (maize, millet, and sorghum) seven years ago. He has a store in Kaboïla I, opposite the Guinso medical clinic. He is a very popular merchant.

Wishing to better serve his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom he is on his first individual loan.

He expects to buy 23 sacks of maize and 23 sacks of millet from the areas surrounding Sikasso. He warehouses the merchandise so that he can then sell it wholesale to a clientele composed of retailers and heads of households.

He expects to use this loan to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow his working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan, investing the rest back into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy cereals for resale

loans.name: Aïssata

texts.fr:
Aïssata M. a 46 ans, mariée et mère de neuf enfants. Elle réside avec sa coépouse,  leurs enfants et leur époux commerçant, à Sanoubougou I-Koulikoro, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame  Aïssata M. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et de vente de  fruits (ananas, avocat, banane, orange, etc) il y a environ six ans. Elle mène son activité devant les locaux des services de  Douanes de Sikasso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle  a décidé de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant deux  ans. Elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel, après avoir bien remboursé le prêt précédent. 
Elle compte acheter, des fruits (en faire un stock) en provenance de la Côte d’Ivoire qu’elle revend en détail ou en gros à une clientèle composée de toutes les couches sociales.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aïssata M., 46, is married and the mother of 9 children. She lives with her co-spouse, their children, and their husband who is a merchant in Sanoubougou I-Koulikoro, one of the outlying neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having tried numerous businesses without success, Mrs. Aïssata M. began to sell fruit (pineapples, avocados, bananas, oranges, etc.) about 6 years ago. She has her salespoint in front of the Customs Office in Sikasso. Wishing to better satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. She is on her second individual loan, after having correctly reimbursed the preceding loan. She intends to stock up on fruit coming from Côte d’Ivoire which she then resells, wholesale or retail, to a clientele composed of all sorts of people. She expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow her working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into the business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fruit (pineapples, avocados, bananas, oranges, etc.)

loans.name: Aref

texts.en:
Aref is a young Palestinian man who is married with four children. He used to work as a daily worker in Israel but, as getting there became quite difficult after 2004, he decided to start his own business as a taxi driver.

Aref has the qualification to drive the taxi and the special license required to drive public transportation but he doesn't have the capital to buy his own taxi. So he made a contract with a friend: his friend will give him the taxi and Aref will pay him a fixed amount monthly.

After deducting all the expenses, Aref has a net profit of 2,000 Israeli Shekel (1USD=3.8 ILS). He is working hard to cover his family expenses since this is the family’s only source of income and he can hardly manage.

Aref request 3,000 USD from FATEN to pay his registration and insurance fees in addition and do some maintenance on his taxi since winter has started.

Aref appears in the photo with the taxi.

loans.use: To pay for taxi maintenance and insurance and registration fees

location.town: Taqou' Village, Bethlehem City, West Bank

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John O. is 40 years old and married with 4 children.

He sells bags of maize at wholesale prices to earn a living. He has a stall where he sells daily from 7 AM to 7 PM. He sells for long hours to enable him meet the basic needs of his family. He has been in this business for a long time.

John hopes to purchase a van in the future to enable him distribute his bags of maize.

John is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more bags of maize to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize to sell.

loans.name: Kalifa

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Kalifa Traoré a 26 ans, célibataire et père d’un garçon, il réside dans une  grande famille traditionnelle, avec ses parents et ses cadets à Kaboïla II, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Traoré est un électricien de profession, qui en parallèle avec sa profession, mène une activité d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques (TV,Mine Chaîne, DVD, etc) à Mancourani I où se situe son atelier. 
Il mène cette activité depuis maintenant quatre ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses articles. 
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Le prêt précédent a été correctement. 
Il compte acheter, 3 DVD, 2 TV, 2 Mines Chaînes, 4 batteries, etc. Ses appareils proviennent de la république du Ghana.
 Monsieur Traoré  vend ses appareils (TV, Mines Chaînes, DVD, batteries, etc) dans son atelier de réparation à ses clients composés généralement de ceux qui sollicitent ses services de réparations.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Kalifa Traoré is a 26-year-old, single father of one son. He lives with a large traditional family, with his parents and his younger siblings in Kaboïla II, the central town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Traoré is a professional electrician who also buys and sells electronic appliances (TVs, Mine Chaîne, DVDs, etc.) in Mancourani I where his shop is located. He has done this for four years now. He is often praised by his clients for the quality of his products. In order to meet the growing demands of his customers, he decided to rejoin the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for his second individual loan. He repaid his previous loan. He plans to buy 3 DVDs, 2 TVs, 2 Mine Chaînes, 4 batteries, etc. This equipment comes from the Republic of Ghana. Mr. Traoré sells his equipment in his repair shop to clients generally made up of those who solicit his repair services. He plans to make a monthly profit of 95,000 FCFA which he will use to increase his working capital, help with his family's expenses, repay the interest on the loan, and invest the rest in his work.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Electronic Equipment (TV,Mine Chaîne, DVD, etc).

loans.name: Heriberto

texts.en:
Heriberto O. is 60 years old, and is married to Martina Florentin who is 55 years of age. All their children are grown and independent.

Heriberto started his business in 2007, with the money gained from selling his car. He invested his capital in the purchase of laundry machines, and opened a Laundromat business. He has a lot of clients.

He needs this loan to renovate his home so that he can continue using profits from his business to further grow his business.

loans.use: Renovation.

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 45 years old. She is divorced and has four children. Currently three of her children are in school.

Dora trades in jewelry and mobile phones. She has been in this business for the past five years. Dora buys her goods from the big shops in the city. She “hawks” (door-to-door selling) with her jewelry from house to house and also treks to nearby markets to sell.

Dora wants to use the loan to buy jewels in bulk so she can trek to other markets and make more income to support her children in school.

loans.use: To purchase assorted jewelry and phones.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is 52 years old. She is a widow and has two children who are currently independent.

She says selling of lingerie especially for women is very profitable and therefore she has been selling ladies jean materials and lingerie by hawking for 15 years.

Vida wants to use her loan to buy bales of lingerie and jeans material to increase her inventory and sales for good income.

She believes this loan would help her save some money and rent a shop where she can sell her stock

loans.use: To purchase assorted lingerie in bulk.

loans.name: Susie

texts.en:
Susie is 47 years old. She has three children. All her children are currently in school. 

To support her household Susie has been selling soft drinks in the neighborhood to her loyal customers. 

She says selling of soft drinks is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make good income to provide for her family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase assorted soft drinks.

loans.name: Jocelyne

texts.fr: G. Jocelyne est née vers 1958 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique au Bénin. Mariée à LASSISSI Razacki un soudeur à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, Jocelyne est mère de six enfants, dont quatre sont à sa charge. C'est depuis 10 ans que Jocelyne réside à Ahito à Allada, avec ses enfants. Jocelyne vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Jocelyne n'a pas été l'école. Depuis près de 10 ans, Jocelyne vend du pain (sucré et salé, petit pain) à Allada. C'est aussi à Allada que Jocelyne s'approvisionne. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'accroître davantage son activité, Jocelyne sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
G. Jocelyne was born around 1958 in Allada, in Atlantique county, in Benin. Married to LASSISSI Razacki, a welder in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, she is the mother of six children. Four of them are in her care. For ten years, she has been resided in Ahito in Allada with her children. She works in aid of her husband to meet family expenses. Jocelyne has not gone to school. For nearly ten years, she has been selling bread (sweet and savory; buns) in Allada. She gets her supplies in Allada as well. She is a previous ALIDé client who has benefited from three loans, which were repaid. With the aim of augmenting her working capital and to grow her business further, she’s requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bread (sweetened breads, savory breads, and buns)

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana F. is 48 years old and is married to Roberto Lopez who is 52 years old. They have three children who are all currently studying.

Juana is a street vendor. She began her business in 2000. Her husband helps her in her business, and together they have built up a large and loyal clientele.

Juana’s dream is to buy a van so that she can sell a greater variety of products and cover a bigger area and market.

She is applying for a loan to buy more merchandise to increase her stock and satisfy the demands of her customers.

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria D. is 43 years old, and has been married to Isacio Santacruz, who is 45 years old, for 19 years. They have two children, 17 and 8 years old, who are both in school.

Maria started her business 22 years ago, before she was married. She has built up a loyal clientele for her business, working with colleges, schools, companies, making uniforms and shirts with their logos. Her husband works in agriculture and has a truck that he uses to transport his produce from his farm to a local factory.

Maria will use this loan to buy more fabric, which she needs to satisfy all her orders this year.

loans.use: To buy fabric and materials.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 52 years old. She is a widow and has two children who are currently working. 
She says selling of lingerie especially for women is very profitable and therefore she has been selling ladies jean materials and lingerie by hawking for 15 years. Agnes wants to use her loan to buy bales of lingerie and jeans materials to increase her inventory and sales for good income. 
She believes this loan would help her save some money and rent a shop where she can sell her stock.

loans.use: To purchase assorted lingerie in bulk.

loans.name: Miguel

texts.en:
Miguel L. is 42 years old and is married to Delia Escobar, who is 34 years old. They have 4 children, all of whom are in high school.

Miguel began his business in 1993 with the money he saved from his salary. When he started he had very few clients and very few products to sell, but his business has since grown to have a wide variety of products and a loyal and large clientele.

Miguel will use this loan to buy more merchandise to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise.

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: A. Eugénie est née vers 1951 et est mariée à ALLAGBE Bernard, un menuisier. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés.  Eugénie vit depuis près de 20 ans à Gbégamey à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique. Eugénie vit avec tous ses enfants, et vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Eugénie n’a pas été à l’école. C’est depuis 50 ans que Eugénie mène comme activité, la vente de produits vivriers (riz, haricot, maïs) ainsi que des divers (sardines, tomates en boîtes, lait, couscous, savons, petit pois, pâtes alimentaires, bougies, etc.) à Allada. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et à Bohicon dans le Zou au Bénin, que Eugénie s’approvisionne. Eugénie a bénéficié une fois de crédit à ALIDé et a bien remboursé le crédit. En vue d’accroître son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Eugénie sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Eugénie was born around 1951 and is married to ALLAGBE Bernard, a furnture maker. The couple has three children who are all in school. For nearly twenty years, she has been living in Gbégamey in Allada, in Atlantique county. She lives with all her children, and she works in aid of her husband to support the family. Eugénie has not gone to school. For fifty years, she has been running a business selling staple goods (rice, beans, corn), as well as a variety of goods (sardines, canned tomatoes, milk, couscous, soaps, peas, pasta, candles, etc.) in Allada. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and in Bohicon, in Zou, in Benin. She benefited once from an ALIDé loan, which she repaid. With the aim of growing her business and to cope better with customer demand, she’s requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy staple foods (tubs of rice, beans, and corn) and canned foods

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia, 47, is married to Caesar, 44, and they have two children who are in school. Silvia is a street vendor who sells clothing, footwear, blankets and quilts. She also has a little store where she sells her products. She has a steady and loyal clientele, which she has built up by offering low prices and high quality products.
Silvia’s dream is to expand her business and offer more products to her customers. She is applying for a loan to buy more merchandise and increase her stock.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 47 years old and has been happily married for 19 years to Francisca Lopez, who is 37. Wilson and Francisca have a daughter who is in the 9th grade.

Wilson now has his own pantry and the business is doing very well. He recently bought a machine for making ice cubes, which has increased his profits as summer nears. He has a lot of customers who value his excellent service and care. Wilson will use this loan to buy a freezer to use in his pantry. His dream is to expand his business and open a food stand.

loans.use: To buy a freezer

loans.name: Shadia

texts.en:
Shadia is the mother of four children. Her husband works as a peddler so he doesn't have a stable income. Things got worse for him after Israel established the separation wall in addition to crossing checkpoints which spread all over the West Bank. That makes it even harder for him to travel between cities.

Shadia decided to help her husband by doing embroidery and selling it to shops, neighbors, and on request. She received several loans from FATEN and repaid them in full and on time. Now she requests 600 Jordanian Dinar (1 JOD=0.71 USD) to buy cloth, thread and beads.

Shadia appears in the photo with one of her products.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, thread and beads

loans.name: Joaquim Albano

texts.pt:
Joaquim J. nasceu no Distrito de Chemba, Província de Sofala, centro de Moçambique, tem 39 anos de idade, casado e pai de 5 filhos de 12, 10, 8, 4 anos de idade, o mais novo com 4 meses de idade, destes os 3 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez 9ª classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras, mas pretende continuar com meios próprios. Vive com a sua família no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, para alem da família não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu de Sofala para Maputo, em 1989 com a sua família, a procura de melhores condições de vida. Em 1998, sai da cidade de Maputo para o Distrito de Boane para fixar a sua residência. Actualmente trabalha na empresa Electricidade de Moçambique (EDM) desde o ano de 2004 faz um horário único das 8h as 15.30h e aufere um salário mensal de 6.000.00mt, poupa algum mensalmente na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu irmão que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 12.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, barrotes, arreia e pedra) para dar continuidade com a sua obra.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente o presente empréstimo, para poder aceder a mais créditos no futuro afim de concluir a sua obra e oferecer o melhor conforto a sua família.
texts.en:
Joaquim J. was born in the district of Chemba in the province of Sofala in the center of Mozambique. He is 39; married; and the father of 5 children who are 12, 10, 8, 4, and 4 months. The 3 oldest go to school. He studied through 9th grade and didn't continue due to the lack of financial resources of his parents. But he hopes to continue studying through his own means. He lives with his family in the district of Boane in the province of Maputo and doesn't support anyone besides his family. He left Sofala for Maputo in 1989 with his family in search of better living conditions. In 1998, he left the city of Maputo for the district of Boane to start his home. Currently he works at the Mozambique Electric Company and has since 2004. He works from 8 until 3:30. He makes a monthly salary of 6,000 meticais and saves some every month in his bank account. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his brother who is also a client of the institution. This is his first loan in the amount of 12,000 meticais, which he will use to purchase construction materials (sheets of metal, bars, sand, and stone) to continue building his house. He promises to pay back his loan on time so he can request more loans in the future so he can finish his home and offer more comfort to his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction material (cement, iron, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Beatrice Wanjiku

texts.en:
Beatrice is 30 years old and married with three children. She has a salon in Ruaka Centre where she offers her services to school students and other ladies from the centre and outside. She has been in this business for eight years now and earns a profit of approximately 40,000 KES per month.
Beatrice has never borrowed from another MFI before, and was introduced to KADET by a friend. She plans to use her loan to buy an extra and better blow dryer for her salon. One day soon, she hopes to operate a school of hairdressing and beauty in Ruaka and other towns. She also hopes to be more efficient in her services in order to increase her turnover and, therefore, her standard of living.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy an extra blow dryer for her salon

loans.name: Kuña Katupyry Group

texts.en:
This group was formed by Gladys Lopez V. who gathered 16 women to work in the Women’s Entrepreneurship program after she heard about it from a friend. The 16 women of the Kuña Katupyry Committee are currently entering their fourth loan cycle and are excited to continue their growth and progress.

The women are enthusiastic about their work and support each other in their businesses and loan repayments. They all work independently, selling clothes, shoes, food, dressmaking materials, etc. They will each receive between 1,200,000 and 200,000 PYG to buy sugar, meat, flour, eggs, noodles, candy and clothing in order to improve their businesses and increase profits to help their families and improve their lives.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Julio Juliao

texts.pt:
Júlio V. nasceu no distrito de Manjacaze, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 30 anos de idade, casado e pai de 3 filhos de 9, 7 anos de idade que vão a escola e o mais novo com 7 meses de idade. Fez somente 5ª classe, devido a falta de recursos financeiros, por parte dos seus progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu de Manjacaze para Boane sozinho ha 7 anos atrás, a procura de melhores condições de vida. Tem um negócio próprio, não tem empregado e vende mais loiça de cozinha onde consegue render cerca de 200.00mt a 400.00mt por dia. Consegue poupar cerca de 600.00mts por mes na sua conta bancária depois de todas despesas de casa.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus amigos. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 12.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar produtos para o seu negócio (panelas, termos, loiça de cozinha e outros) para responder a demanda do mercado. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 10.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt ambos para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente, pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para poder ampliar a sua obra e oferecer melhores condições de Habitação a sua família.
texts.en:
Júlio V. was born in the district of Manjacaze in the province of Gaza in southern Mozambique. He is 30; is married; and is the father of 3 children who are 9, 7, and 7 months. The oldest 2 go to school. He finished studying only through 5th grade due to his parents' lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and doesn't support anyone besides them. He left Manjacaze for Boane by himself 7 years ago in search of better living conditions. He has his own business. He doesn't have any employees and sells kitchen supplies. He manages to save around 600 meticais a month in his bank account after paying all of his home's expenses. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his friends. This is his 3rd loan, and it is for 12,000 meticais. He will use it to buy products for his business (pots and pans, thermoses, kitchen supplies, etc.) to respond to market demand. His previous loans were for 10,000 meticais and 15,000 meticais, and both were used for the same purpose. In the future, he hopes to request more loans to be able to expand his home so he can provide better living conditions for his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell various kitchen supplies

loans.name: Alice

texts.pt:
Alice da Conceição M. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província capital de Moçambique, tem 35 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 3 filhos de 17, 14, 10 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 7ª classe, parou devido a Gravidez precoce. Vive na casa própria com a sua família em Boane no bairro 5, não sustenta mais ninguém. 

Saiu da Matola para Boane, em 2008 com a sua família após a conclusão da sua obra em Boane. Tem um negócio próprio a 2 anos, vende mais frangos que compra o pinto a 19.00mt e vende o frango a 95.00mt, tem 2 trabalhadores e trabalha das 9h, as 14h. O seu rendimento mensal é de cerca de 5.000.00mt, com o qual sustenta a família e poupa através do sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa (Xitique).

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seus vizinhos. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 11.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (pintos e ração) para aumentar a quantidade de frangos e responder a demanda do produto na quadra festiva que se avizinha.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este crédito para poder aceder a mais empréstimos. No futuro pretende comprar uma viatura que ira lhe ajudar no transporte de sua mercadoria.
texts.en:
Alice da Conceição M. was born in the city of Maputo, the capital of Mozambique. She is 35; married; and the mother of 3 children who are 17, 14, and 10. All of them go to school. She studied only through the 7th grade and stopped due to an untimely pregnancy. She lives in her own home with her family in neighborhood 5 in Boane. She doesn't support anyone besides her family. She left for Matola for Boane in 2008 with her family and built her home in Boane. She has had her own business for 2 years and buys and sells chickens. She buys chicks for 19 meticais and sells the chickens for 95 meticais. She has 2 workers, and she works from 9 am.-2 p.m. Her monthly income is around 5,000 meticais, with which she supports her family and saves some via a tradtional rotating savings system known as Xitique. She has never had a loan with another bank. She became familiar with Hluvuku through her neighbors. This is her first loan and it is for 11,000 meticais. She will use it to buy chicks and feed to increase her quantity of chickens and respond to the demand for her product during the holiday season that is approaching. She promises to pay back this credit on time so she will be able to receive more loans. In the future, she hopes to buy vehicle that will help her transport her merchandise.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To raise chickens

loans.name: Kabagyenda 6 Kiteteyi Jovilate Group

texts.en:
K. Jovilate is 50 years old, married and has 12 children, of whom 11 are schooling. She also looks after two dependants who are also at school.
For over 15 years, Jovilate has run a pub business. The capital in her business has dropped and she is therefore requesting a loan to purchase local brew to sell to her customers, and jerricans for carrying it, in order to improve upon her capital as well as her profits. The loan will be used to increase her stock which, due to large profit returns, will enable her to pay her children's school fees.
Jovilate is an active and hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to improve and expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase local brew and jerricans for carrying it

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.en:
This group was formed in Caaguazú when Ms Ortiz gathered a group of women after she learned about the Women’s Entrepreneurship program. She brought together 17 women, all of whom were enthusiastic about working together to take out a loan to improve their businesses. They are currently entering their fifth loan cycle and are excited to grow further.

The group members have decided to use their loan to invest further in their businesses. They have received between 300,000 and 1,200,000 PYG each depending on the size of their business. They used their loans to buy sugar, meat, flour, eggs, noodles, cheese, candy, and clothing such as jeans, shirts, skirts and lingerie. They share a common goal to improve their businesses and the lives of both themselves and their families.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 46 years old and married with five children. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. Victoria is a hardworking woman who sells baby things, and one of her greatest joys is the one-to-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.
She is requesting a loan of 120,000 NGN to purchase more baby things to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby things to sell

loans.name: Morgado

texts.pt:
Morgado B. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 29 anos de idade, casado e pai de 2 filhos de 2 anos de idade, e outro de 4 meses. Fez 12ª classe, actualmente continua o ensino a distância. Vive com a família numa casa alugada e ainda sustenta a mãe que vive também em Boane enviando dinheiro para despesas de casa.

Nunca saiu da sua cidade, em 2001 terminou com o curso de Professor, no Distrito da Manhiça e foi enquadrado no Ministério da Educação como Professor afecto em Boane e trabalha das 7h as 12h por dia. Aufere um salário de 5.700.00mt por mês, poupa algum na sua conta bancária.

Já teve empréstimos numa instituição de crédito (TCHUMA), depois de conhecer a Hluvuku preferiu iniciar os seus empréstimos, sendo este o seu 4º crédito, no valor de 11.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (ferro, cimento, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 8.900.00mt,13.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt, todos para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimo para concluir a sua obra, comprar mobiliário e concluir o ensino superior.
texts.en:
Morgado B. was born in southern Mozambique, in the district of Boane, Maputo province. He is 29 years old, married, and father of two children, 2 years old and 4 months old. He completed the 12th grade, and continues with distance learning. He lives with his family in a rented house, and takes care of his mother who also lives in Boane, sending her money for her household expenses. In 2001 he finished teacher's training in the district of Manhiça and was assigned by the Ministry of Education as a teacher in Boane, working from 7 to noon each day. He earns a salary of 5700 MZN a month, and manages to save some in his bank account.

Morgado used to take out loans from a credit institution (TCHUMA), but after learning about Hluvuku he chose to start getting loans through them. This is his fourth loan, in the amount of 11,000 MZN. He plans to buy construction materials (rebar, cement, sand and other) to finish building his house. The previous loans were in the amounts of 8900 MZN, 13,000 MZN, and 15,000 MZN, all for the same work. He would like to request additional loans in the future to finish his house, purchase furniture, and finish his higher education.

Translated from Portuguese by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials (cement, rebar, sand and others)

loans.name: Simao Israel

texts.pt:
Simão Israel M. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, tem 33 anos de idade, casado e pai de 6 filhos de 15, 12, 9, 6, 4 e 2 anos de idade, destes 4 vão a escola. Fez somente 5ª classe, não continuou por falta de condições financeiras por parte dos pais. Vive na casa própria em Boane com a sua família e sustenta sua mãe, enviando dinheiro.

Saiu de Boane para Suazilândia, a procura de emprego, depois de varias dificuldades enfrentadas, decidiu voltar a Moçambique 2 anos depois. Actualmente tem um campo agrícola e conta com 4 trabalhadores, produzem e vendem Hortícolas (feijão verde e repolho) juntos com a sua esposa. Desenvolve esta actividade desde o ano de 2002 e  rende trimestralmente cerca de 45.000.00mt, poupa algum na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que também são clientes da mesma instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 30.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar insumos e pagar jornas de trabalho para produção de hortícolas (batata, pimento, pepino e outras) como forma de satisfazer a sua clientela. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 12.000.00mt, 16.000.00mt e 20.000.00mt, todos para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para poder aumentar a área de cultivo e introduzir novas culturas, por isso compromete se a pagar bem este empréstimo também.
texts.en:
Simão Israel M. was born in the District of Boane in the province of Maputo. He is 33; married; and the father of 6 children who are 15, 12, 9, 6, 4, and 2. Of these, 4 of them are in school. He only studied through 5th grade and didn't continue due to his parents' lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home in Boane with his family and supports his mother by sending her money. He left Boane for Swaziland to look for a job. After facing several difficulties, he decided to return to Mozambique 2 years later. He currently has some farmland and has 4 workers. He grows and sells vegetables (green beans and cabbage) along with his wife. He has done this activity since 2002 and makes about 45,000 meticais a quarter and saves some in his bank account. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through neighbors who are also clients of the same institution. This is his 4th loan and it is for 30,000 meticais. He will use it to buy supplies and to pay his workers to produce vegetables (potatoes, peppers, cucumbers, etc) as a way to satisfy his customers. His previous loans were for 12,000, 16,000, and 20,000 meticais, and they were all used for the same purpose. In the future he hopes to request more loans to be able to increase his farmland and introduce new crops. This is why he promises to pay back his loan on time.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To produce vegetables and grains

loans.name: Byaaba 2 Ahimbisibwe Feleska Group

texts.en:
A. Feleska is 32 years of age, married, and blessed with four children, two of whom go to school.
For more than four years, Feleska has been dealing in produce such as maize and beans. Her stock is insufficient to meet customer demand, and she is therefore requesting a loan to purchase more bags of maize and beans for resale.
Feleska is a promising businesswoman whose future hope is to educate her children and purchase some land.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize and beans

loans.name: Sebastiao Joao

texts.pt:
Sebastião João M. nasceu no Distrito de Inharrime, Província de Inhambane, tem 40 anos de idade casado e pai de 2 filhos de 12 e 6 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. É bacharel em engenharia agrícola, formado na Holanda. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, sustenta 2 irmãos e sobrinhos enviando algum valor para o seu sustento.

Saiu de Inharrime para Maputo em 1988, para continuar com os estudos, depois de concluir no Instituto Agrário de Boane, viajou para Holanda onde fez o seu bacharelado. Trabalha como técnico Agrónomo a 17 anos, das 8h as 16h, e tem um salário mensal de 12.530, poupa algum valor na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu amigo que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 5º empréstimo no valor de 26.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pagamento de mão de obra, e ferro) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os anteriores créditos foram de 16.000.00mt, 15.000.00mt, 25.000.00mt e 40.000.00mt todos foram para a mesma actividade.

O objectivo é de ver a sua obra terminada para oferecer melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família. Futuramente pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir um estabelecimento comercial e abrir sua machamba.
texts.en:
Sebastião João M. was born in the district of Inharrime in the province of Inhambane. He is 40, married, and the father of 2 children who are 12 and 6. Both of them go to school. He has a bachelor's degree in agricultural engineering, which he received in Holland. He lives in his own home with his family, and he supports his 2 brothers and their children by sending them some money. He left Inharrime for Maputo in 1988 to continue his studies. After he finished studying at the Agrarian Institute in Boane, he traveled to Holland where he got his bachelor's degree. He has worked as an agricultural technician for 17 years. He works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. and makes a monthly wage of 12,530 meticais. He saves some of it in his bank account. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his friend who is also a client of the institution. This is his 5th loan, and it is for 26,000 meticais. He will use it to purchase construction materials (cement, iron, and to pay for labor) to continue building his home. His previous loans were for 16,000, 15,000, 25,000, and 40,000 meticais. All of them were used for the same purpose. His goal is to finish his home so he can offer better living conditions to his family. In the future he hopes to request more loans to build a commercial establishment and to start a small farm.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials and to pay for labor

loans.name: Esperanza De Nuevo Horizonte Group

texts.en:
This committee was formed through the initiative of Blanca E., who heard of the program and decided to join with 22 other humble workingwomen who must earn their daily livelihood.
The group members are independent in their work. Some work as street vendors selling clothes, others own pantries where they sell food, still others sell silver jewelry from street stalls or have gardens and sell their products in the local market. They will receive an average credit of 450,000 PYG each, which they will invest in their businesses, buying sugar, flour, eggs, noodles, meat (pork, beef, chicken), cassava, soft drinks, candy, vegetable seeds, and clothes such as jeans, shirts, skirts, lingerie, silver jewelry, etc.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 37 years old, married with four children, aged between 2 and 12. He lives in the Gicumbi district in the northern province of Rwanda which is approximately an one hour's drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Jean Bosco has been a butcher for 13 years. His immaculately clean shop provides the community with quality meat products at fair prices. His business hours are from 7 AM to 4 PM every day except Sunday.

This is Jean Bosco's second loan - he paid back on time and in full his first loan from VFC. The reason why he is requesting his second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company is to purchase more goats and cows for slaughter. As it stands, demand outstrips his available supply each day. Jean Bosco is certain he will make more profits with this loan to purchase more product to sell. With the profit which is not reinvested in his business, he will continue to save for his family as well as pay for any immediate family problems for his extended family.

loans.use: Purchase more goats and cows to slaughter

loans.name: Kikoni Ambulire Jennifer Group

texts.en:
A. Jennifer is 31 years of age, married, and blessed with three children, all of whom go to school. She is the group representative of this loan group.
Jennifer has been running a pub business for seven years. She is requesting a loan to purchase items for the pub, such as crates of soda, beers, wines, boxes of water, and so on. She wishes to increase the stock in her business to make more profit.
Jennifer is a hardworking businesswoman whose future hope is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase crates of soda, beers, wines, boxes of water, etc. for her pub

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 39 years old and she is married with four children. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She sells household items in front of her house and, with the business, she is able to assist her family's basic needs and other necessities.

With the loan of N50,000, she plans to expand her business, which is now booming. With this kind of business she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to provide better for her children's education. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more household items to sell

loans.name: Kaja Group

texts.en:
Mwasiti M. is 37 years old, married, and has three daughters, Diana (18), Miriam (16), and Amy (13). 

Mwasiti has been a businesswoman since 1990 since she was just 18. She is in the clothing business, buying clothes in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and selling them in Arusha, a city eight hours north by bus. She says that Arusha has "bei mkubwa sana," or "very big prices," compared to Dar.

Mwasiti works from 8 am til 10 pm every day, making a monthly profit of about 300,000 TZS ($225). She uses her profit to care for her family, paying for school fees, food, and health care costs.

This is Mwasiti's fifth loan from Tujijenge, Tanzania. She has repaid all of her previous loans successfully, and wants to use this one to buy more dresses, kangas, shoes, pants, and other accessories to increase the variety of her goods. 

She believes increasing the variety of the items she sells will help her business become more profitable. 

In the photograph, Mwasiti is seated second from the right in the front row. She and all of her group members are from the Makumbusho area of Dar es Salaam. 

Mwasiti will share this loan with the members of Kaja group. The group loan will help support the businesses of six photographers, three clothes sellers, a video shooter, two shop owners, two salon owners, a fish vendor, and one woman who sells radios and TVs.

The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy dresses, kangas, shoes, pants, and other accessories to increase business stock.

loans.name: Floride

texts.en:
Floride is a 43-year-old widow with four children aged between 4 and 16. In addition, she has two dependents from another family whom she cares for. Floride lives in Western Province of Rwanda, which is approximately three hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Floride sells potatoes to customers throughout her community. This is only her second year in this business but she is fairing well so far. She puts in long hours although she is not able to specify the exact time: she explains that she works from early in the morning until late in the evening every day, five days a week.

Floride is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase a greater quantity of potatoes at better prices which she expects will help her to increase her monthly profit. With some extra profit, she will be able to reinvest in her small, growing business. With the remaining profit, she will continue to provide more and better food for her children and dependents as well as putting away a little bit of money for their future.

loans.use: To purchase more potatoes at better prices

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is excited to take out a Kiva loan. She will use this loan to invest in a business selling household items, which she will buy in bulk to get a better price. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family.

She is married with 4 children and she is 46 years old. She lives in Warri, Delta State, Nigeria. She plans to add the selling of gift items to her business if the loan amount of 70,000 is given to her. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more household items to sell

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean de Dieu is 47 years old and is married with four children aged between 9 and 17. He and his family live in Gicumbi in the Northern Province of Rwanda.

Asked why he began his business, Jean de Dieu recounts that his jobs were not paying enough money and he needed to make a better living for himself and his family. So, four years ago, he started a business selling clothes which he saw was a gap that needed to be filled in his community. Jean de Dieu's clothing business is open from eight in morning to five in evening every day except Sunday.

Jean de Dieu is requesting his first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders to allow him to purchase a line of more modern styles of clothes for sale. He thinks his customers will appreciate the new, attractive clothes he provides. He also plans to “use his resources more efficiently” so that he can offer lower prices and still make a profit. He hopes that he can do this so that his customers will benefit because they will get more modern clothes at lower prices.

With his profits, Jean de Dieu will reinvest in his business to grow it larger still.

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of clothes for sale (formal and casual)

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en: Nilda has a rice farming business in Norala, South Cotabato. She is married to Joel. They have 5 children; the eldest is 18 years old. She strives hard to survive the difficulties of life. She wants a better life for her family. She does not have enough capital to improve her business. That's why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. She needs this loan to further improve her farming business.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Ma. Shellane

texts.en:
Ma. Shellane, 39, is an entrepreneur from Norala, South Cotabato. She owns a 1-hectare rice field where she manages a rice farming business. She enjoys her work on the farm and, at the same time, supports the needs of her family. She was able to send her 2 children to school because of her farm.

She heard about how Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) offers financial assistance for entrepreneurs like her. Now she has been a member of CEVI since 2008. She would like to request a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies and fertilizers

loans.name: Ma. Liza

texts.en:
53-year-old Liza has a rice farming business in Norala, South Cotabato. She tills a 2-hectare rice field to move her family out of poverty. She has 6 children to support. She wants her children to have a better future someday. That's why she works so hard to have a better life.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to gain a chance to make her business grow. Now she's requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos to purchase farm supplies needed for her rice field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah B. has been in the rice farming business since 1986. It is her family's only means for earning a living. She is now 41 years old with 2 children. She tills a 2-hectare rice field. Though the land is not theirs, she maintains it very well, making use of the opportunity given to them.

She's now requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to support her business. The loan will help her to buy farm inputs in order to have a good harvest in the future.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Eileen

texts.en:
Eileen, 38, is a mother of two children. She is married to Rene, and they live in Norala, South Cotabato. Together they work hard in their 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field. The income is enough to provide for their daily needs. Her eldest child is 16 years old. They want their children to finish their studies.

Eileen asked for support from Community Economice Ventures, Inc. to provide a loan of 15,000 PHP. This loan will be used to buy farm supplies and fertilizer to improve her farm.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: C1198 Rwambona Ya Iii Group

texts.en:
Ildephonse is the president of a group called “Rwambona ya III”. He is 43 years old and is married with two children aged 10 and 14 years. They live in Gicumbi, in Northern Province of Rwanda which is a forty-five minute drive from Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. Ildephonse is a proven entrepreneur with five successful years in the business of selling beverages: sodas and beer. 

The members of Rwambona ya III have seen that the number of their customers has increased more than the quantity of inventory that they are able to purchase. For this reason they are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company so that they can afford to purchase more beverages in greater quantities and at lower prices. This, Ildephonse explains, will satisfy their customers, increase their sales and result in more profits – all good things!

Any additional profits from this loan, the members of this group will reinvest in their business in order to build more secure futures for their families.

loans.use: To purchase more beverages (sodas and beer) for sale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha sells fairly used clothing at market in the city of Warri, Nigeria.  She is 37 years old and married with four children. Martha  is a focused, hard worker who puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more inventory to sell. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase fairly used clothing for resale

loans.name: Honorata

texts.es:
La socia HONORATA pertenece al banco comunal “MERCAMUEBLE” y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. 

La socia tiene 30 años de edad, es soltera y tiene un pequeño restaurante. 
Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con la atención de su restaurante. Ella prepara comida todos los días desayuno, almuerzo y cena. Su restaurante se encuentra ubicado muy cerca del mercado “MERCAMUEBLES” donde se venden muebles, el mercado esta ubicado en el primer paradero del distrito de San Sebastián de la provincia del Cusco. Ya son varios años con esta actividad y le ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone para en su trabajo.
       
La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio de venta de comida quiere comprar más insumos como arroz, aceite, azúcar, etc. Para preparar más platos de comida.    

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Honorata belongs to the Mercamueble Communal Bank. She lives in the Imperial city of Cusco. She is 30, single, and has a small restaurant. She alternates her activities between her household and the restaurant. She makes breakfast, lunch, and dinner everyday. Her restaurant is located very close to the Mercamuebles Market, where they sell furniture. The market is located at the first bus stop in the San Sebastían district, Cusco province. She has been doing this for many years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She needs a loan to increase the capital in her food selling business. She wants to buy more supplies like rice, oil, and sugar, etc. to prepare her dishes. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to make her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital in her food selling business

loans.name: Mujeres Activas Group

texts.en: This committee was formed by Pascuala G., who invited her neighbors to participate in the program and join the group with the goal of working to offer their children a better lifestyle. There are 15 independent women in this group who sell clothes, food, and cleaning supplies. Each woman uses her  share of the loan to buy goods for sale such as sugar, flour, eggs, milk, meat, and soft drinks, as well as jeans, shirts, skirts, shirts, lingerie, and raw fabric and materials to sew articles of clothing.

loans.use: To purchase goods for resale

loans.name: Rita Cuna

texts.pt:
Rita Cuna C. nasceu na cidade da Matola, província de Maputo, tem 42 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos de 15 e 12 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Não estudou, perdeu os pais muito cedo e não teve quem fizesse seu acompanhamento. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos e um sobrinho que perdeu os pais.

Mudou se da Matola para Boane há mais de 10 anos, altura em que havia conseguido um espaço para construir a sua casa. Actualmente é comerciante e dona do seu próprio negocio a 12 anos sem trabalhadores os filhos tem ajudado sempre que necessário. Vende mais roupa usada e consegue render cerca de 1.000.00mt a 2.000.00mt por dia. Poupa através do Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku porque esta perto da banca onde ela trabalha. Este é o seu 7º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar fardos de roupa usada para diversificar ainda mais o seu produto e satisfazer o seu mercado. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 3.200.00mt, 5.000.00mt, 5.000.00mt, 8.000.00mt, 15.500.00mt e 20.000.00mt todos aplicados para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente gostaria de terminar a sua obra e solicitar mais empréstimos para canalizar a água para a sua casa.
texts.en:
Rita Cuna C. was born in the city of Matola in the province of Maputo. She is 42, single, and the mother of 2 children who are 15 and 12. They both go to school. She never went to school. She lost her parents very early and never had anyone to support her. She lives in her own home with her children and her nephew who lost his parents. She moved from Matola to Boane over 10 years ago because she had obtained a space to build her home. She currently is a merchant and has owned her own business for 12 years. She doesn't have employees and her children always help her when she needs it. She sells used clothing and earns between 1,000 and 2,000 meticais a day. She saves money through a traditional rotating savings system known as Xitique. She has never had a loan with another bank. She became familiar with Hluvuku because it is near the bank where she works. This is her 7th loan and it is for 25,000 meticais. She will use it to buy bundles of used clothing to diversify her products even more and satisfy the market. Her previous loans were for 3,200, 5,000, 5,000, 8,000, 15,500, and 20,000 meticais and were all used for the same activity. In the future, she would like to finish building her home and to request more loans to pipe water to her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell clothing

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam, 39 years old, is married and has 5 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells groceries in her retail stall to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time and hopes to own a super market in the future.  Marian is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries for sale. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is a fifty one year old woman. She is divorced and has six children who are currently independent. She trades in herbal medicine.  She treks to the big cities to purchase stock and retails to her customers. She does not have enough working capital to stock in bulk.  With the loan, she wants to purchase more stock, which will allow her to scale up her sales, and make enough profit to support her family. She believes the loan will enable her, to save more income, to support her grandchildren who live with her.

loans.use: To procure natural medicine in bulk.

loans.name: Jean Nepomuscene

texts.en:
Jean Nepomuscene is 23 years old and is married with one child who is six months old. He lives in the Gicumbi district which is in the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately a one hour drive from Kigali, the capital city.

Jean Nepomuscene has been a proven entrepreneur using a motorcycle-taxi since 2006. He works very hard at his business - the hours he operates his job are from early in the morning until late in the night every day of the week. He enjoys his job as he serves his community through transporting them to and from the border between Rwanda and Uganda where many entrepreneurs go to purchase different goods for sale.

After realizing that motorcycle-taxis are still in short supply in this area and that they are so useful to entrepreneurs, Jean Nepomuscene had the idea of purchasing a second motorcycle to rent to others for them to earn a living so that he can make a profit as well. He thinks like a true entrepreneur!

In order to purchase this motorcycle, Jean Nepomuscene is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With this second motorcycle, he will create another job for one person and above that, he will increase his monthly profit as well. With this profit,he will create some other sources of income which will help him to save the money needed to build the house he has dreamed of owning for many years.

loans.use: To buy another moto-taxi

loans.name: Antonio Magaiza

texts.pt:
António Magaiza M. nasceu no Distrito da Manhiça, Província de Maputo, tem 44 anos de idade casado e pai de 2 filhos de 17 e 12 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 1ª classe, não continuou porque perdeu os pais muito cedo. Vive na casa própria, sustenta um sobrinho órfão de mãe.

Saiu da Manhiça para o Distrito de Boane em 1969 transferido pelos serviços, posteriormente decidiu fixar a sua residência e buscar a família para residirem em Boane. Tem um negocio próprio a 19 anos, vende produtos da 1ª necessidade das 7h as 19h com a ajuda da sua esposa. Nesta actividade consegue render cerca de 1.000.00mt por dia, poupa algum mensalmente na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outras instituições financeiras, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu vizinho que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos de 1ª necessidade para o seu negócio (açúcar, óleo, arroz e outros). Os créditos anteriores foram de 10.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt ambos para a mesma actividade.

No futuro, pretende solicitar mais créditos para poder aumentar a área de cultivo na sua machamba e reforçar o produto do seu negócio para responder a demanda da sua clientela.
texts.en:
