loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
It is usually hard to raise a big family. Dedication and hard work is required to support all of the needs of the family. But for Teresita S., this problem did not arise because she is lucky that her husband Alberto strives hard to provide for their family in spite of his low income as a farmer.
Teresita is now 51 years old with 11 children who range in age from 10 to 32 years old. Most of the younger ones are still in school but the older children are already working and helping to support the family. This family of 13 lives in the village of Bi-ao, in the town of Binalbagan, Negros Occidental.
To help her husband support their family, Teresita started with pig fattening and raising chickens, selling the chickens in the local market after raising them for 45 days. This venture became a family affair as the younger kids were able to help with the chores of feeding the animals and cleaning their pens, which were all located in the backyard of their house.
Seeing that she could earn a respectable income from such an activity, Teresita wanted to expand her pig fattening and chicken operations but she needed additional capital to buy the piglets and the chicks. This is the reason why she decided to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000. 
With access to additional funds, she was able to increase the number of animals and was also able to start a general store adjacent to their house. Now her lowest monthly profit is 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from these business activities. This has a big impact in defraying their household expenses and has enabled her to set aside some money for the higher education of her children. They have also been able to buy a small sugarcane farm that her husband now manages.
Her previous loan of PHP29,500 was used as additional capital for her business activities and now that she has paid that off, she is borrowing the same amount of PHP29,500, which she intends to use to buy more stock for her general store, feed for her piggery, and fertilizer for their sugarcane farm. She hopes to use the profits to make improvements to their household.  


 About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store and other businesses

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana S. is from the village of San Roque, Maramag, Bukidnon. She is 58 years old. Susana is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To earn a living, Susana owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Susana has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Susana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was very helpful for her business. Susana is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to continue her business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Susana from HSPFI. She plans to reinvest the additional business profits into her business and to pay off her credit. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating her business

loans.name: Chharm

texts.en: Chharm T., 37, lives in the Takeo province with his wife and four young children. He works at a local painting company. He typically makes about $5 per day. His wife is a farmer and makes less than $1 per day. Chharm T. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S. is from the village of Hubangon, Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Jocelyn is married. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Unn

texts.en: Unn S. is 40 years old and resides in the Takeo province with her husband and two young children. Since 1990, she has been selling chickens to earn a living and is able to make about $7.00 of profit each day. Her husband, pictured here, is a farmer who is able to make $1.00 a day. Unn S. would like to take out a loan of $500.00 for her husband to use to purchase cows that will assist his farm work.

loans.use: To purchase cows.

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad M. is from the village of Tonggo in Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Trinidad is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Trinidad runs a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Trinidad has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,600 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Trinidad joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Trinidad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC that she used to purchase additional products to sell. Trinidad is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. This will be Trinidad's 6th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Lonh

texts.en: Lonh S. is 65 years old and married. She lives with her husband and two of her children at the Takeo province. To earn a living, she has been selling fish at the local market. She typically makes about $5.00 of profit every day. Her husband is too old to continue works and is currently staying at home. This couple is aided by two of their children, who are garment factory workers. Lonh S. is asking for a loan of $600 to purchase sewing machines for her children to start a tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel B. is from the village of Isis. She is 49 years old. Maribel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel runs a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Maribel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC that she used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to additional grocery stock for her sari-sari store, as well as livestock feed and other supplies for her secondary business, a piggery farm. This will be Maribel's 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business for future emergencies and use for the education of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase grocery stock and other supplies for secondary business

loans.name: José Daniel

texts.es: José Daniel M. de 44 años de edad, reside en el departamento de La Unión, junto a sus dos pequeñas hijas y su esposa. El posee una tienda en su casa de habitación, la cual esta ubicada frente a una escuela, lo cual contribuye a obtener mayores ganancias. José solícita un préstamo, ya que desea surtir su negocio y mejorar las ganancias, debido a que este es el único soporte económico que posee. José es una persona muy amable y responsable, el cual anhela brindarles una mejor vida a su esposa y a sus hijas y así mismo brindarles un mejor futuro a sus pequeñas niñas.
texts.en:
José Daniel M. is 44 years old, and lives in the La Unión region with his two small daughters and his wife. He has a store in his house. It is located in front of a school, which contributes to higher earnings. Jose is requesting a loan, since he would like to stock his store with merchandise to increase his earnings, given that this is the only economic support that he has. Jose is a very friendly and responsible person who is eager to provide a better life for his wife and his daughters, and also a better future for his small daughters.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy perishable grocery products

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun S. is 23 years old and married. She lives with her husband and one young child in the Takeo province. She and her husband together have a business making incense. On average, they make a about $5.00 of profit each day. Bun S. has an idea to raise pigs to earn additional income to help raise their standard of living. With this business plan, she is asking a loan of $600.00 to get this business started.

loans.use: To start a pig rasing business.

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin S. is 42 years old and married. She lives with her six children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than $1.00 each day, while her husband is a motor-taxi driver making $3.00 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Yin S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $700.00 so that her husband can purchase a new trailer.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer.

loans.name: Dina

texts.es: Dina G. de 58 años de edad, reside en Usulután junto a su madre y dos hijos. Ella comercializa helados y paletas en su lugar de residencia. A pesar que es un negocio pequeño, ella ha logrado sacar a delante a su familia a través de este, es por esto que Dina solicítia un préstamo, con el fin de surtir su negocio con mayor cantidad de helados y paletas de diferentes precios y sabores, con el fin de  atraer la atención de una mayor cantidad de clientes. Dina es una mujer trabajadora, la cual busca una vida estable, razón por la cual desea mejorar su negocio y obtener mayores ventas.
texts.en:
Dina Gomez is 58 years old and resides in Usulutan together with her mother and two children. She sells ice cream and popsicles out of her home. Although it is a small business, she has managed to help her family get ahead. Dina is requesting a loan for the purpose of stocking her business with a greater quantity of ice cream and popsicles of different prices and flavors, in hopes of attracting the attention of more clients. She is a very hard-working woman in search of a stable life, for which she desires to improve her business and obtain better sales.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of ice cream for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fruit to expand the business.

loans.name: Elia Del Carmen

texts.es: Elia del Carmen S. P.  de 49 años de edad, reside en Ilopango en el departamento de San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres pequeños hijos todos menores de edad. Elia posee una pequeña tienda en su hogar, negocio el cual ella desea ampliarlo y poder surtirlo, ya que este le permite ayudarle a su esposo con todos los gastos del hogar. Ella solicita un préstamo, el cual le permita realizar el sueño de mejorar su negocio, surtirla con más productos como pan, sodas, golosinas, entre otras cosas más, ya que para ella su tienda representa una gran ayuda, la cual le permite brindarles todo lo necesarios a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Elia del Carmen Sanchez Perez is 49 years old and resides in Llopango in the department of San Salvador. She lives together with her husband and their three small children. In her home, she operates a small store, which she desires to expand and to be able to stock, since it enables her to help her husband with the domestic expenses. She is requesting a loan, which will allow her to realize her dream of improving her business, stocking it with more products such as bread, soda, and candy, among other things. For Elia, her store represents a great help, which enables her to provide everything necessary to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase perishable food products

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Khun M. is 23 years old and lives with her young child and her husband in the Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker who is able to make about $3 of profit every day. Her husband, pictured here, has a business as a motor-taxi driver. He typically makes $7 per day. Khun M. is asking for a $700 loan for her husband, who needs to purchase a new trailer.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer

loans.name: Rosa Amelia

texts.es:
Rosa Amelia S. de 59 años de edad, reside en Soyapango en el departamento de 
San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo, dos hijos y un nieto. Ella posee una tienda la cual tiene como nombre “tienda Conchi”, negocio el cual ha contribuido durante 26 años a los gastos del hogar y le ha permitido a Rosa y su esposo brindarles todo lo mejor a sus hijos. Rosa solícito un préstamo a través del cual pueda invertir más en su negocio comprando productos de primera necesidad, los cuales tienen mucha demanda en el lugar. Todo esto permitirá que Rosa siga adelante con su tienda y pueda tener la dicha de verlo mucho más surtido de productos y de esta manera percibir mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Rosa Amelia Sanchez is 59 years old and resides in Soyapango in the department of San Salvador. She lives together with her husband, two children, and a grandchild. She owns a store named "Tienda Conchi", which for 26 years has contributed to paying her home expenses and has enabled Rosa and her husband to provide the best for their children. Rosa is requesting a loan in order to be able to invest more in her business, purchasing essential products that are in high demand in her region. All of this will allow Rosa to continue moving forward with her store and to have the good fortune of seeing it better stocked with products, and therefore receive greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase essential products for her store

loans.name: Uy

texts.en:
Uy S., 37, is married with two children. One of his children is enrolled at a local high school. He resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with his wife and children. To make a living, he is a supervisor at a small place that produces bricks. He earns an income of $7.50 per day. Also, his wife is a worker at that place, earning an income of $2 per day. 

Mr. S. and his wife are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to open a money-exchange shop at a local market in the town.

loans.use: Open a money exchange shop

loans.name: Yuon

texts.en:
Yuon T., 49, is married and lives with three of his children in the Takeo province. He works as a farmer together with his wife and they typically make $1.50 every day. They are also supported by their children, who work in the garment factories and in construction. 

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also forced food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians. In light of these times of economic difficulties, Yuon T. is asking CREDIT, a Kiva partner, for a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for his children to commute to work. (Yuon T. is pictured with his wife at home.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: María Ana

texts.es: María Ana G. D. V.  D. 51 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Cuscatlán junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como agricultor y tres hijos los cuales se dedican a estudiar. María como toda una mujer responsable la cual goza D. muy buena reputación por ser una mujer trabajadora, la cual se esfuerza por brindarles todo lo mejor a sus hijos y D. esta manera contribuir con los gastos del hogar con su esposo, posee una venta D. carne D. pollo, especias y consomés en el mercado Municipal D. Cojutepeque. María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más pollo fresco y cajas D. pollo congelado, D. manera que pueda brindar mayor variedad a sus clientes.
texts.en:
María Ana G. D. V. is 51 years old, and lives in the Cuscatlán region with her husband, who works as a farmer, and three children who are in school. Maria, as any responsible woman, enjoys a very good reputation for being a hardworking woman who strives to proviD. the best for her children and contribute to the household expenses with her husband. She has a business selling chicken meat, spices and soups in the municipal market of Cojutepeque. Maria is requesting a loan which will enable her to buy more fresh chicken and boxes of frozen chicken, so that she can proviD. a greater variety to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy chicken

loans.name: Chuch

texts.en:
Chuch I., 49, is married and lives wI. her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make about $2 of profit every day, while her husband earns $3 a day as a moto-taxi driver. This couple has four children and all of them are employed as garment-factory workers. 

Chuch I. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk so that she can weave more clothes to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase silk

loans.name: San

texts.en:
San S., 26, is married with a young child. She resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with her husband (pictured) and child. To make a living, she sells various kinds of groceries at a local market, earning an income of $15 per day. Her husband operates his motorbike as a taxi driver, earning approximately an income of $6 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike with a compartment attached (Tuk Tuk) for her husband to improve his business.

loans.use: Buy a Tuk Tuk

loans.name: Nhek

texts.en:
Nhek S. is 29 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She sells grocery items and weaves silk clothes to sell at the local market. She typically makes about $3 per day, while her husband earns less than $1 a day as a farm worker. This couple has two school-aged children. 

Nhek S. is asking for a loan of $1,200 as her husband needs to purchase cows to assist with his farm work.

loans.use: To purchase cows

loans.name: María Teresa

texts.es: María Teresa V. D. F.  D. 42 años D. edad, resiD. en Cojutepeque, junto a un hijo el cual se dedica  a estudiar  y dos nietos. María teresa posee un comedor desD. hace cuatro años, el cual le ha permitido solventar todos los gastos D. su hogar, a pesar que ella recibe remesas D. una hija la cual resiD. en Los Estados Unidos, esto no le da a basto ya que lo invierte en los gastos D. sus nietos. Es por esto que María Teresa Solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio, comprando mesas y sillas nuevas y así mismo comprando materia primar para la elaboración D. la comida.
texts.en:
María Teresa V. D. F. is 42 years-old and lives in Cojutepeque, with her son, who is a student, and her two grandchildren. María Teresa has a cafeteria she has operated for four years, a business that has allowed her to take care of the household costs. Although she receives remittances from her daughter who lives in the United States, that money is not enough for all the costs, as it is invested in the expenses of the grandchildren. For this reason María Teresa is asking for this loan in order to improve her business by buying new tables and chairs, and also by purchasing more raw material for the preparation of the food.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tables and chairs.

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Teresa Reina

texts.es: Teresa Reina R. D. P. D. 38 años D. edad, resiD. en La Libertad junto a su esposo y su hijo. Ella elabora y comercializa tortillas en el patio D. su casa en donD. las personas llegan a comprar su producto. Teresa solicita un préstamo, ya que desea mejorar su negocio, comprando más maíz, el cual es la materia prima D. las tortillas, así mismo desea comprar una plancha (nombre que se le da a las cocinas que se utilizan para cocinar las tortillas), la cual cuente con la capacidad para cocinar mayor cantidad D. tortillas. A través D. este negocio es como Teresa pueD. ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos familiares, es por ello que considera D. mucha importancia mejorar las condiciones D. este.
texts.en:
Teresa Reina R. D. P. is 38 years old and lives in La Libertad with her husband and son. She makes and sells tortillas from the front of her house where people come to buy them. She would like a loan because she wants to improve her business by purchasing more corn which the main ingredient in tortillas. She would also like to buy a griddle on which the tortillas are maD.. With a griddle she'll be able to make a larger amount. It is because of this business that Teresa can help her husband with the family expenses making a big difference in their living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Sierra Visher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen materials

loans.name: Nil

texts.en:
Nil S. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in the Takeo province. He is a taxi driver who is able to make a living of $2 of profit every day. His wife, pictured here, has a business selling rice and food and also grows watermelons on her farmland. She typically makes a combined income of about $3 a day. 

Nil S. is asking for a loan of $1,200 as his wife needs to rebuild and reinvest in her food stand.

loans.use: To rebuild and reinvest in his wife's food stand

loans.name: Fredervinda

texts.es: Fredervinda S. Vda. D. A. D. 56 años D. edad, resiD. en Jayaque en el departamento D. La Libertad. Ella posee una panadería en su propia casa, lugar en el cual comercializa el pan. Ella solicita un préstamo ya que desea mejorar su negocio y comprar más materia prima para la elaboración del pan, productos como harina, azúcar, manteca, entre otras cosas más. Fredervinda desea mejorar las ganancias D. su negocio ya que es la única fuente D. ingresos que ella tiene, debido a que vive sola y esta es su forma D. trabajo a través del cual ha logrado seguir adelante.
texts.en:
Fredervina S. Vda. D. A. is 56 years-old and lives in Jayaque in the department of La Libertad. Fredervina owns a bakery installed in her home, from which she sells bread. She is asking for this loan in order to improve her business and purchase more raw material for the making of the bread, products such as flour, sugar, and butter, among other things. Fredervinda wishes to improve her profits from the business as it is the only source of income she has, due to the fact that she lives alone. Through this business she manages to carry on.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw material for the production of bread.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng S., 36, is single and resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with one of her brothers. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling a few kinds of vegetables at a local market, earning a gross income of $20 per day. Her brother helps her in the business by using his bicycle to transport the vegetables to the market every day. 

S. and her brother are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike to easily transport vegetables for sale.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike

loans.name: María Del Transito

texts.es: María del Transito C. D. B. D. 54 años D. edad, resiD. en Colón en el departamento D. La Libertad, junto a su esposo D. 60 años D. edad que se dedica a trabajar como comerciante. María del Transito tiene una venta D. frutas y verduras en la placita la bendición en Colón. Ella solícita un préstamo ya que desea poder comprar mas frutas y más verduras, puesto que desea mejorar las ganancias D. su negocio. María es una persona muy responsable y dedicada la cual se esfuerza mucho por tener una vida digna.
texts.en:
María del Transito C. D. B. is 54 years old, and lives in Colon (in the department of La Libertad) with her 60-year old husband, who works as a trader and merchant. Maria del Transito operates a stand selling fruits and vegetables in the La Bendicion market in Colon. She's requesting a loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables, which will allow her to increase her profits. Maria is a very responsible and dedicated person who works hard to live a positive, worthwhile life.

Translated from Spanish by Jim Muir, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ana Luz

texts.es: Ana Luz L. D. D. D. 51 años D. edad, resiD. en Ciudad Arce en el departamento D. La Libertad, vive junto a su esposo y sus hijos. Ella posee una librería en su propia casa, en la cual comercializa cuadernos, lápices, borradores, entre otras cosas más. Ana solícita un préstamo con el fin D. poder surtir la librería, ya que se acerca la temporada en la que inician clases. Ana espera mejorar sus ganancias y apoyar a su esposo con los gastos familiares.
texts.en:
Ana Luz L. D. D. lives in Ciudad Arce in the department of La Libertad. She lives with her husband and children. She runs a bookstore out of her house where she sells notebooks, pencils, erasers, and other things. Ana applied for this loan in order to restock her inventory because it is back to school time. Ana hopes to increase her profits and help her husband with the family expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products for bookstore

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Leoum

texts.en:
Leoum M., 51, is married with five children. Three of his children are enrolled at a local high school. He resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with his wife and children. To make a living, he operates his motorbike as a taxi at the local markets in the town, earning an income of $5 per day. The family is also assisted by two of his children, who are employed as construction builders, earning an income of $3 each per day to help cover the family expenses. 

Mr. M. and his wife are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, M. is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase rice from the local farmers in the province to store and sell back when the price is good enough to make a profit.

loans.use: Buy rice in stock for resale

loans.name: Griselda Concepción

texts.es: Griselda Concepción A. D. S. resiD. en Ciudad Arce en el departamento D. La Libertad, vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos menores D. edad. Griselda junto a su esposo poseen una venta D. accesorios para vehículos. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda invertir en su negocio y comprar más accesorios. Griselda junto a su esposo son dos personas las cuales son muy apreciadas por sus vecinos los cuales los describen como personas D. excelente comportamiento y muy responsables.
texts.en:
Griselda Concepción A. D. S. lives in the department of La Libertad with her husband and three young children. Along with her husband, Griselda has a store that sells accessories for cars. She applied for the loan to invest in her business and buy more accessories. Griselda and her husband are well respected by their neighbors who describe them as having excellent behavior and being responsible.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vehicle accessories for business

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Sonia Esperanza

texts.es: Sonia Esperanza J. D. M. D. 38 años D. edad, resiD. en Ilopango junto a sus tres hijos menores D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Sonia posee una venta D. tortas, las cuales son elaboradas D. carne o jamón y las comercializa sobre la calle principal D. Ilopango. Sonia solicita un préstamo para poder comprar un carretón donD. pueda elaborar y vender las tortas, ya que el que posee es un carretón alquilado. Ella como madre soltera desea mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio, ya que es la única fuente D. ingresos con la que cuenta para brindarles todo lo necesario a sus tres pequeños hijos.
texts.en:
Sonia Esperanza J. D. M. is 38 years old and lives in Ilopango with her three young children, who are all studying. Sonia makes beef and ham sandwiches, which she sells along the main street of Ilopango. Sonia applied for the loan to purchase a cart where she can make and sell her sandwiches. She currently has to rent a cart. As a single mother, she wants to improve her business because it is the only income with which she can proviD. all the necessities to her three small children.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a food cart

loans.name: Julio César

texts.es: Julio césar M. A. de 41 años de edad, reside en Ilopango junto su esposa, su hijo y tres sobrinos todos menores de edad. El posee una tienda en su propia casa, así mismo realiza viajes para otras personas ya que posee un pick up y así mismo vende gas propano. Julio solicita un préstamo para poder surtir su tienda con productos como pollo, pan, lácteos, entre otros más. Julio césar es una persona con muy buenas referencias de sus vecinos, el cual se destaca por tratar de diferentes maneras de  brindarle lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en:
Julio César M. A. is 41 years old and lives in Ilopango with his wife, son, and three young nephews. He runs a small shop out of his house, works as a driver for other people because he owns a pick up, and sells propane gas. Julio applied for the loan to be able to offer more products for his store like chicken, bread, and dairy products among others. Julio César has good references from his neighbors who note the many different ways he tries to improve his family's life.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of perishable products

loans.name: Ana Deysi

texts.es: Ana Deysi S. D. A. D. 28 años D. edad, resiD. en Sensuntepeque en el departamento D. Cabañas, vive junto a su esposo, su madre y tres hijos menores D. seis años D. edad. Ella posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos perecederos y así mismo posee un ciber café. Ana solícita un préstamo ya que desea poder surtir su tienda con muchos más productos, ya que esta está ubicada en las cercanías del hospital general D. Sensuntepeque y así mismo desea comprar equipo nuevo para el ciber café debido a que también hay una escuela ubicada cerca del lugar.
texts.en:
Ana Deysi S. D. A. is 28 years old and lives in Sensuntepeque in the department of Cabañas. She lives with her husband, her mother, and her three children, all of whom are under the age of six. She has a shop where she sells perishable products and also runs a cyber café. Ana applied for the loan because she wants to offer more products at her store because it is located near the general hospital of Sensuntepeque a high traffic area. She also wants to buy new computers for the cyber café because there is also a nearby school.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of perishable projects

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is from the village of Benoni, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 33 years old. Elizabeth is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Ana Yanci

texts.es: Ana Yanci P. de 26 años de edad, reside en Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad, vive junto a su esposo, el  cual es empleado de una empresa privada. Ana posee una venta de ropa para personas de todas las edades, el negocio esta ubicado en el centro de Ciudad Arce y ella es muy conocida por las personas por ser una mujer muy responsable, la cual comercializa ropa de primera calidad y precios muy accesibles. Ana solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más ropa y de esta manera aumentar la mercadería y ofrecer mayor variedad de productos a sus clientes.
texts.en:
26-year old Ana Yanci P. lives in Arce, in La Libertad department. Her husband works for a private company. Ana owns a business located in the centre of Arce selling clothing for people of all ages. She enjoys a reputation as a very responsible woman. The clothing she sells is high quality at good prices. Ana is asking for a loan so she can buy more clothes and in this way increase her stock and thus offer a greater choice to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing

location.town: Ciudad Arce en el departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia M. runs a variety store selling food and daily use products in her community. She is 49 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Langcangan, Mahinog Camiguin. Patricia has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2008, Patricia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Patricia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used for additional business capital. Patricia is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Caroline's Group

texts.en: Caroline B. is a 32-year-old hard-working and determined lady, and the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She has had a clothes store in Lugazi Town council for 3 years and she is able to make 30,000UGX as profits a week, which is mostly affected by the seasonality of her business plus the high rent costs. Caroline likes her business very much and in future, she would like to increase her business capital for increased stock. She would also like to have her children educated, as well as to build a family house for comfort. She is married with 3 children aged 13 years, 10 years and 1 week old, and she takes care of 5 dependants. Caroline needs a loan to help increase her business capital by purchasing more clothes for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita A. is from the village of Walkway within Catarman, which is in the Camiguin Province of the Philippines. She is a 46-year-old married woman with two school-age children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector; specifically, she runs a food stall. Indeed, her main source of income comes from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in this business for over six years, and she typically earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosita joined HSPFI to get access to financial services; by doing so, she gained the ability to engage in business activities, and, in turn, she improved her family's standard of living. Notably, Rosita has already successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rosita is now requesting a second loan from HSPFI, this time in the amount of of 8,000 PHP ($175), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated as a result of this loan to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and it seeks to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional products

loans.name: Nelda

texts.en:
Nelda M. is from the village of Anito, which is within the Mambajao Camiguin Province of the Philippines. She is a 46-year-old single woman with one school-age child. To earn a living, Nelda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector; more specifically, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of income is derived from selling both food and everyday products to her local community members. Nelda explains that she has been engaged in this business for over 12 years, and that she typically earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Nelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services; as a result, she was able to engage in business activities, and, in turn, to improve her family's standard of living. Importantly, Nelda has already successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI in the amount of 14,000 PHP, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. In fact, the loan that she is now requesting would be the fifth loan taken out by Nelda from HSPFI. Indeed, Nelda is now seeking another loan from HSPFI, this time in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325), which will again be used to purchase additional products for resale purposes. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and its mission is to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional products

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Lagunde, which is within the Mambajao Camiguin Province of the Philippines. She is a 31-year-old married woman with two school-age children. To earn a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector; more specifically, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store. Her main source of income is derived from selling a variety of different products to her local community members. Elizabeth explains that she has been engaged in this business for over four years, and that she typically earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services; as a result, she was able to engage in business activities, and, in turn, to improve her family's standard of living. Elizabeth is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which will be used to purchase additional products for resale purposes. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and its mission is to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional products

loans.name: Ayub's Group

texts.en:
M. Ayub has had a boutique in Bukamunye for one and a half years. He is a married man with nine children between the ages of 1 and 18, as he takes care of his siblings. He is a determined man and he is lucky that he is able to make 80,000/= profit a week. Before having a boutique, Ayub was a fisherman. He does not regret the change, although his business is affected by high competition. He ensures that he treats his customers well and has quality clothes for resale; hence, more sales. In the future, Ayub wants to be a wholesaler so that he can build a house for his family.

Ayub needs a loan to be able to restock his boutique with more clothes for a steady supply of products. He is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi.

loans.use: To restock his boutique with more clothes

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros O. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old, married, and she has 6 adult children.

To make a living, Milagros sells a variety of viands in the community. She has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,600 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Milagros joined HSPFI to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI.

Milagros is requesting her fifth loan, for 11000 PHP, which she will use to purchase more ingredients for her food business. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family’s income.

About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients for her  food business.

loans.name: Fedencia

texts.en:
Fedencia M. lives in Palao1, Brgy. Balintawak, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She is 60 years old and married to Hermigeldo M., who is a fisherman. The couple have 15 children who range in age from 13 to 42 years old. The older children already have their own families and live separately from their parents, while the single adult kids who still live at home help with the family expenses. Most of the younger children still go to school.

Fedencia herself could not believe that she could raise 15 children, but she said that they did all this with God’s help and their own tireless efforts, patience, perseverance and most of all, love. Now, even at 60, she continues her business pursuits in the hope that she can provide a good future for her younger children.

When they first started life together, Fedencia was well aware that her husband had no fixed income and that their livelihood solely relied on the fish he caught each day. As their family grew, Fedencia realized that she had to contribute to the family income, so she started a small general store adjacent to their house. Her business helped a lot in defraying their household costs, which was why Fedencia thought of expanding her operations so that she could increase her income potential. The need for additional capital moved her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon, a Kiva partner,  in 2005.

The additional capital allowed her to earn more than her previous income and the store now earns a minimum monthly income of 2,000 Philippine pesos. Also, with the additional income, she was able to raise livestock, which she sold for additional profits. 

For her previous loan, she borrowed PHP 18,000 to purchase additional stock for her general store. This time around, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 for her seventh loan cycle with NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she can consistently purchase new stock when her store’s inventory is depleted. She is determined that, while she is able, she will continue working until all of her children are either gainfully employed or established in their own livelihoods.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Bernandena

texts.en:
Bernandena N.'s main source of income comes from buying and selling fruit like banana products. She is 61 years old, married and has 3 school-age children. She is from the village of Tru-cut, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. Bernandena has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Bernandena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Bernandena is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children and for allowances.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
L. John is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is 36 years old, married, and has five children aged 5, 7, 9, 11 and 13. They are all in primary school. John also takes care of seven dependants, including orphans.
John is a hardworking man and has been a boda-boda rider for Lugazi Town Council for the past five years. He shows good customer care towards his clients. His business is seasonal, which affects his cash flow. He is able to make 20,000 UGX a week profit. He has a dream of buying his own bike so that he could earn a larger income and continue to educate his children to the last level. John is requesting a loan to purchase a cow (with a top-up from his savings) so that he could sell milk to diversify his family income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Daysi Lilian

texts.es: Daysi Lilian F. D. R. D. 40 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. La Libertad, vive junto a sus dos hijas menores D. edad. Ella posee un comedor, en el cual elabora desayunos y almuerzos. Daysi solícita un préstamo ya que desea invertir en el para poder obtener mayores ganancias, ya que ella es la única que vela por el bienestar D. sus hijas, y su mayor deseo es brindarles una vida llena D. todo lo necesario para vivir D. manera adecuada.
texts.en:
40-year old Daysi Lilian F. D. R. and her two young daughters live in La Libertad department. Daysi owns a small restaurant where she serves breakfasts and lunches. She is asking for a loan to invest in her restaurant so that she can earn more money--she is sole support for her children. Her greatest wish is to proviD. them with the necessities for a good life.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy food ingredients

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora L. is from the town of Sapang Dalaga. She is 28 years old. Flora is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Flora owns and operates a mini-restaurant in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Flora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Flora is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP to expand her business. This will be Flora's 6th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

To make a living, Teresita raises, harvests, and sells a variety of vegetables for sale. loans.name: Unia's Group

texts.en: Unia N., the leader of her lending group, is a very determined business lady with a strong drive to succeed. Unia owns a pub where she sells beers, sodas, wines and spirits to her customers, as well as selling waragi. She says that her busiest hours are usually in the evenings after people have left their work to relax and socialize with friends. Customers often enjoy drinks until the late evenings at Unia's popular bar. She would like a loan to buy more crates of beer to increase her stock and improve sales.

loans.use: Buying more crates of beers, wines, spirits and sodas

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet, 27 years old, is a single mother with a 6 year old child who is currently in school.  Annet rents a one room house where she lives with two other people. The family has access to electricity and no piped water and gets three meals a day.   

Annet works seven days a week in a semi urban area located on the outskirts of Kampala. She has a business selling all types of vegetables at a stand. On average, she receives 40 customers a day. Her major business challenges are seasonality and ever increasing prices of vegetables in Uganda due to drought in villages. She also incurs significant transportation to buy tomatoes, onions and other vegetables.  She has been in this business for over five years. MCDT is currently servicing her sixteenth loan. Annet joined MCDT because it was near her home and was easy to work with it. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of onions and baskets of tomatoes. She is aspiring to own another stall in Nakulabye.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of onion, boxes of tomatoes and cabbages

loans.name: Meldrin

texts.en:
Meldrin O. is from the village of Pandan, Mambajao Camiguin Province. He is 38 years old. Meldrin is married and has 1 school-aged child.

To make a living, Meldrin buys and sells "copras" or dried coconut meat in the local market. Meldrin has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Meldrin joined HSPFI to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meldrin is requesting his first loan of 5000 PHP which he will use to purchase additional products to sell.

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.name: Clemencia

texts.en:
Clemencia P., 54 years old, is from the village of Sto.Niño, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is married and has two older children. To make a living, Clemencia owns and operates a hair salon and beauty parlor. While not the only means for generating revenue, she has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Clemencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clemencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide services. Clemencia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand her business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Clemencia from GDMPC. loans.name: Roquesa

texts.en:
Roquesa O. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 43 years old. Roquesa is married and has 9 school-aged children.

To make a living, Roquesa provides transport services to local community members. Roquesa has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In July 2008, Roquesa joined HSPFI to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roquesa successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI which she used for maintenance for her two motorcycles.

Roquesa is requesting her fifth loan, for 16000 PHP, which she will use to purchase materials needed to provide better service.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income.

loans.name: Lurcille

texts.en:
Lurcille B. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old. Lurcille is married and has 2 adult children.

To make a living, Lurcille operates a fishing business. She harvests and sells ocean-caught fish in the local community. Lurcille has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lurcille joined HSPFI to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lurcille successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI.

Lurcille is requesting her fourth loan, for 10,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional fish to sell. It’s Lurcille's discretion to maintain its loan amount.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income.

About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica P. is from the village of Poblacion, Catarman, which is within the Camiguin Province of the Philippines. She is a 42-year-old married woman with three school-age children. To earn a living, Jessica owns and operates a business venture in the food sector; more specifically, she operates a food production business. Her main source of income is derived primarily from selling a variety of snack food and "halo-halo" (a popular dessert in the Philippines) to her local community members. Jessica explains that she has been engaged in this business for over 20 years, and that she typically earns approximately 2,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Jessica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services; as a result, she was able to engage in business activities, and, in turn, to improve her family's standard of living. Importantly, Jessica has successfully repaid a previous loan in the amount of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. In fact, this loan that she is now seeking would be the fourth loan taken out by Jessica from HSPFI. Jessica is requesting another loan from HSPFI, this time in the amount of 11,000 PHP ($250), to purchase new items so that she can expand her product offerings. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and its mission is to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing new items

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is a 52-year-old widow with five children. Her children are between the ages of 14 and 22 years old, and all of her children are currently attending school. She resides in and owns a four-room house, where she lives with six people. Teopista also takes care of additional family members. Thankfully, her family has access to electricity and piped water, and they are able to eat three meals per day.

To earn a living, she operates a poultry business. Teopista works seven days per week in a semi-urban area (in the outskirts of Kampala), and she averages approximately 20 customers per day. She explains that she sells to all categories of customers (i.e., retail and wholesale customers), and that she incurs transportation costs when buying chicken feed and feeding trays. Her major business challenges are the ever-increasing prices of chicken feed and chickens in Uganda. She has been in this business for over 20 years, and she has been with MCDT for eight years. Notably, this would be Teopista's twentieth loan via MCDT. Teopista joined MCDT because it was near her home, and because it was an easy organization to work with. She would like to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feed and chickens. She aspires to own 5,000 chickens someday.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional feed and chickens

loans.name: Felipe

texts.en:
Felipe Paca, Jr. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, which is within the Camiguin Province of the Philippines. He is a 25-year-old married man with two infant-age children. To earn a living, Felipe Jr. owns and operates a business venture in the services sector; more specifically, he operates a transportation business. Indeed, his primary source of income is derived from transporting local community members around town with his habal-habal (motor-cycle) taxi. Felipe Jr. explains that he has been engaged in this business for over three years, and that he typically earns approximately 3,500 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2009, Felipe Jr. joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services; as a result, he was able to engage in business activities, and, in turn, to improve his family's standard of living. Felipe Jr. is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP ($125), which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide his taxi service. This loan would be the first loan taken out by Felipe Jr. from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve/expand his business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and its mission is to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve his business by purchasing additional materials

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara E. is from Bañaderos Ozamiz City, Philippines. She is a 55-year-old widow who has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Clara owns and operates a business venture in retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste to the local community. Clara has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Clara joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services and she has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. Clara is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional additional product to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Clara from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Bernabe would like a loan of 7,000 PHP that he will use to purchase farm supplies. The couple want their children tp finish a higher level of education because this is the only thing they could give to them. So they work hard to continually support the schooling of their children. Bernabe would be glad if his loan request is granted.

Diomer, 45 years old, is married to Elvie and they have five children: Jovelyn, 23, an undergraduate at college; Jonalyn, 22 years old; Jocelyn, 19 years old; Joelson, 12 years old is in primary school and Diomer Jr., ten, is an elementary pupil.

He hopes to obtain a loan amounting PHP15,000 for him to provide for the needs of his family. This loan amount could be a big help in meeting their daily needs in life.

loans.name: Loreto

texts.en:
Loreto is managing his rice farm in the village of Amulungan, Rizal Santiago City. He is happily married to Milarnie R. and they have six children: two of them are already married and have their own families and four of them are still single: Rowena, 22, is a high school graduate; Loreto Jr.,19, completed only grade-IV due to lack of funds; Rhea, 14, is a 1st year high school student and Reina Mae, 8, is a grade-I pupil. The couple works hard to support the schooling of their children.

Rice farming is the main source of income of Loreto and his family. So, he is doing all his best to have high yields. He would like to buy all the farm supplies needed in his farming but his capital is not sufficient and he is requesting additional capital amounting PHP30,000 that will be used in buying fertilizer, pesticides and other supplies needed to have high yields. Through his loan he would be able to purchase all those things so he is praying that this amount will be provided.

loans.use: Buy farming supplies

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
This is Aida P., 47 years old, who is the wife of a court stenographer. She has three children; one is in college and another is in high school. They live in Bagong Silang, Caloocan City. Aida is into the buying and selling of ready-to-wear (RTW) dresses. At times she also sells dried noodles. She earns more than P3,000 a month, and a little more during the holiday season. She uses her profits to support the education of her children.

Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative, Aida has enjoyed the many benefits it provides its members, who are mainly housewives. She is now on her third loan cycle with CCT. She has applied for a fresh loan from the cooperative in the amount of P9,000 to serve as additional capital.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing to sell at her store

Albert dreams of having high yields because this is the main source of their income. He hopes to borrow additional capital from KIVA lenders for the maintenance of his rice farming business. He wishes to get a loan amounting PHP 30,000 in order to purchase fertilizer, pesticides and other important things needed in his rice farming business. This amount of loan will be a big help in growing his business.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a 53 year old widow with two children aged 27 and 31 years. Neither of her children go to school. She resides in a four room house she owns, where she is staying with six people. Aisha takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day. She doesn’t incur any transport costs to and from buying food because she works at the very market where she buys the food.

Aisha works seven days a week in a semi urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people in retail and wholesale. She has a restaurant in Owino Market and sells all types of food plus tea. Her major business challenge is ever increasing prices of food due to famine in many villages of Uganda. She has been in this business for over ten years and with MCDT for five years, now servicing her fifteenth loan. Aisha joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was easy to work with. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, cassava, and sweet potatoes. She aspires to own a fully refurbished hotel.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, cassava, and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is 54 years old and is married to Luisa who is a store owner. The couple are active ASKI clients and have a good record. They have six children but one of them is already married and lives separated from them. Five are still single and they are: Rey - 27 years old who is pursuing his vocational course; Elmer - 26 years old, a college graduate; Joy - 25 years old, a high school graduate; Jennylyn - 17 years old, a high school graduate; and Diosa - 8 years old, a grade-IV pupil.

Alex owns and operates their fish pond and rice farming businesses. He is thankful because his children help him in cultivating and tilling their rice farm. Alex is on his 3rd agricultural loan. He is an active client and that’s the reason why he is able to obtain this program.

Alex would like to develop and buy a feed supply for his fish but he lacks capital so he would like to apply for a loan of PHP 14,000. He would be thankful if his request loan is granted because through this he will be able to make his business grow.

loans.use: To buy a feed supply for his fish

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia D. C. lives and does business in Baclaran - a commercial district between the cities of Paranaque and Pasay City. She is 55 years old and lives with her two children.

Leticia owns and manages a bakery which is open to customers twenty-four hours a day (24/7). She also has a general store where she sells banana cue and coconuts. She opened her bakery a few years ago with only an assistant working at the oven. Now her bakery employs nine bakers who rotate as store attendants as well. She earns at least P30,000 a day from the combined operations of the bakery and the general store.

She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. The easy-to-pay and low-interest loans provided by the cooperative allow her to purchase bakery supplies and store merchandise in bulk amounts, saving her a lot of time and money. She has currently applied for a new loan in the amount of P48,000 to use as additional capital for her businesses.

Leticia believes that education would be the best gift she could give her children, so she works hard to better improve her businesses. She finds fulfillment in that from her profits and savings, she is able to send her children to reputable schools.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase bakery supplies and other merchandise for a general store

loans.name: Mumina

texts.en: Mumina is 22 years old and married to Abdikadir Godana. She has operated her retail shop in Naivasha town for the last two years. Mumina was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her second loan. She repaid her first loan well. She plans to use the cash from this loan to add more dry foodstuffs in bulk to her shop's stock (sugar, wheat, maize flour and rice) in preparation for the festive season which will see demand for these dry foodstuffs go up. Mumina hopes to open a supermarket in the future to serve the clients from her area who currently have to travel long distances to get to one. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita P. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old. Nelita is married and has 2 school-age children. To make a living, Nelita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nelita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Nelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita is 51 years old and is married to Victor, a farmer in their village. They have six children and four of them are already married and have their own families. Her other two children are still single and they are still studying. They are: Elizabeth - 16 years old, who is 4th year high school; and Roderick - 12 years old, a grade-IV pupil. Lolita’s husband is a responsible father and very supportive of Lolita's business.

Lolita’s vending business is improving and yet she still wants to continue its growth for her children’s needs. She would like to ask financial support of PHP 8,000 from Kiva lenders as revolving capital for purchasing additional fruits, vegetables, meat, food and other snacks that she sells in their village. In this matter she hopes to be able to gain more profit for the improvement of their daily living.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for buying more goods to sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita E. is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. She is 47 years old, is married, and has three adult children.

Lolita owns and operates a business providing photography services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

Lolita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Juma Zia Group

texts.en:
M. Juma is the son of M. A. who is the group leader of Juma Zia group. He is married and he lives in district 2 in Kabul Afghanistan. This group is made up of two members each one of them is busy with different tasks. M. Juma has a tailoring shop. With the loan he would like to buy the essential materials for his business.  Gull Sib, the second member of this group wants to take a loan for his son who has a fresh fruit shop. With the loan he receives he would like to expand his business and purchase more fresh fruits to attract more clients.
They want to take a group loan of 20000 Afghani to develop their businesses and they are confident that they will repay their loans on time. They would like to thank Kiva for their help.

loans.use: they want to purchase the things they need

loans.name: Melvin

texts.en:
Melvin, 49, is a farmer from Norala, South Cotabato. He works very hard on his one hectare (2.5 acre) rice field in order to have a good harvest.

Melvin is married to Ailyn and they have three children. His eldest child is only 9 years old.

Melvin heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and that it offers financial support for entrepreneurs. He joined CEVI and is requesting a loan of 15,000 Php. This amount will be very helpful to him, enabling him to invest more in his rice-farming business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Safari

texts.en: Safari M., 32, owns a retail kiosk (called Tawakal) and a barber shop.  He is hardworking and likes to be busy. Safari has three sons, ages 3 to 7, who he hopes will be able to obtain high-school education and live a comfortable life.  Safari's kiosk is located on a shopping street in Tudor, a residential area outside Mombassa, and it sells baked goods, eggs, cereals, sodas, cooking fats as well as an array of household products, such as batteries, cloth, and lotions. Safari has been in the business for eight years, working in the store together with his wife.  He will use the current loan to improve his retail sales business by increasing the inventory of the store.

loans.use: Increase of store inventory

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita G. is from the village of Hubangon, Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Tita is married and has 2 school-age children.
