To make a living, Tita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Tita has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Tita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. Tita is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Tita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the  education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina, engaged to Lorenzo, has six children: Darwin, 27 years old, Efren, 26, George, 25, Lorenzo Jr., 22, Lorena, 21, and Kerovin, 17. Most of Rufina's children have already obtained college-level education. 
Rufina makes a living for her family by selling Ready To Wear clothes (RTWs) and fruit in the local community. Her fiancé Lorenzo is a farmer, cultivating and tilling rice, and through his work earns the main share of the family's income. Rufina currently needs additional funds (approximately PHP 12,000) to be able to develop her sales business. Specifically, she will use the money to buy additional RTWs to respond to the many orders.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Los

texts.en: Los S., 43, is married with two school-age children. Her children are enrolled at a local high school. She resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she sells food (lunch, dinner, and breakfast) at her home, earning  an income of approximately US $5 per day. Her husband is a public school teacher, earning an income of US $4 per day to help cover the family expenses. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $1200 to expand her business by purchasing tables and other additions to aid her restaurant. (Los S. is pictured holding a dish to spoon food for her customers).

loans.use: To buy tables and other restaurant additions

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 58 years old and has 2 children who are both currently at school. She earns income working as a farmer in Norala, South Cotabato, managing a 1.5-hectare rice field. She devotes most of her time to working on the farm in order to be able to support her family. 

Myrna recently joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and is requesting a loan of PHP12,000. She will use the money to improve her farm's productivity in order to obtain a more plentiful harvest in the future.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Khan

texts.en: Khan C. S., 29, is married with two school-age children. Her children are enrolled at a local primary school. She resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children. To make a living, she sells a few types of fish that she usually buys from local farmers, earning approximately an income of US $4 per day. Her husband operates a business of renting discs of movies and karaoke songs to her new and existing customers at a local market, earning an income of US $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase more discs to stock her husband’s disc shop.

loans.use: To buy more discs to stock the store

loans.name: Noel

texts.en: Rice farming is the main source of income for Noel, 41, from Norala, South Cotabato. Noel tills a 1.5-hectare rice field and currently needs additional capital to support his farm. He has therefore joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to have a chance to obtain a loan. Noel has requested PHP15,000, which he will use to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Fertilizers and farm inputs

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Hang Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan is being taken out by 18 people who all live in Trapeang Trakiet village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sam H. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. She is facing an obstacle of being unable to water her crops because her water pump needs to be repaired. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to fix her pump so that she can water the field and make the crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Ngaet Phat, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Sam H. is a mother of two children, one of whom is working in a garment factory while the other is studying at home and doing house work.

loans.use: To fix her pump in order to water the field and make the crops more productive

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
Ariel G. is from the village of Comon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 32 years old. Ariel is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Ariel owns and operates a business selling grilled chicken and pork in the local community. Ariel has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month doing these activities.

In 2009, Ariel joined Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ariel is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Ariel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ikechukwu

texts.en: Ikechukwu, 32, is married and has a child. He lives in Ogbomoso, in the Oyo State of Nigeria, and makes an income selling male clothes and shoes at a retail store. Ikechukwu is a very hard-working man and has been in this business for a long time.  Currently, it is the high season for his business, and Ikechukwu hopes to be able to meet the high demand from his customers and, thus, earn additional income for his family. Ikechukwu is requesting a loan of NGN50,000 to purchase more clothes for sale. He is thankful to all Kiva lenders for support.

loans.use: Purchase of additional clothes for sale

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad S. is from the village of San Roque, Maramag, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old, single, and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Natividad owns & operates a business making & selling snacks such as hot cakes and bananas in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Natividad joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was very helpful in providing for the needs of her family. Natividad is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in her business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Natividad from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income and pay off her weekly loan obligations to HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen D., 30, is married with two school-aged children, both enrolled in a local primary school. She resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. Her husband operates a business as a realty agent, earning an income of US$3 per day to help cover the family expenses.

D. sells various kinds of groceries, earning an income of approximately US$2 per day. She and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and to generate a better income. Therefore, D. is asking for a loan of US$300 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her grocery business

loans.name: Mrs. Savon Khun Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan consists of fifteen people, all of whom live in Preak Ta Ong village in Kandal province. Mrs. Savon K. has been selected by the village bank members as their president. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land used for cultivating rice. She needs fertilizers and pesticides to support her business because her soil is infertile, so she has decided to ask for a loan to purchase these supplies. Her husband, Mr. Ma Vibol, is a construction worker who supports the family with his small income. The couple have two children; the elder is attending the local school, while the younger is too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes S. is from the town of Alicia, Isabela. She is 25 years old, is married, and has two infant children. Lourdes operates a restaurant, serving lunch foods to customers in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately Php 3,000 a month. In 2009, Lourdes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. She is requesting a loan of Php 5,000 which will be used to add other menus to her restaurant business. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To add other menus to her restaurant business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Novie

texts.en:
Novie is a mother of three children. She manages a rice-farming business in Norala, South Cotabato. She works hard to improve the land and the crops she planted in order to have a good harvest. At the age of 38, her eldest child is 9 years old. She wants to continually support her family through her farm.

She heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner that offers financial assistance with low interest rates. She became a member of CEVI in 2008. Now she would like to request a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy fertilizers and necessary supplies for her farm.

loans.use: Fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Akinyemi

texts.en:
Akinyemi sells clothes and colorful sarongs at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to own a boutique in the future. His greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction he has with his customers. 

The festive season is here and he hopes to make more profits. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. He is 30 years old and married. He hopes to have children very soon. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato T. is from Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 37 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Renato owns and operates a business selling musical instruments and prayer and worship materials to tourists and local community members. He also offers musical tutorial services. Renato has been engaged in his business for over six years and earns a gross income of approximately $1130 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Renato joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Renato is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services he provides. This will be his 4th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand the services he provides

loans.name: Nasaret A1 Group

texts.en:
Frans S. is 37 years old and the leader of the Nasaret A1 Group. He was born into a farm family. He is a married man and has one son, Minggas S., who is 9 years old and studying in the first grade of elementary school. Frans lives with his family in Nenas Village, Fatumnasi Sub district, Kapan – South Central Region of Timor. Nenas lives far away from downtown. It takes about two and a half hours to travel from the Kapan Branch Office. Even though categorized as a cloistered place, Nenas Village is surrounded with a beautiful view. 

In order to meet his family's needs, Frans has to work hard by cultivating carrots, leeks and vegetables. The traders from Kupang city usually come to buy his agricultural products, so he doesn’t have to sell them at the market. The income that he generates from selling agricultural products helps him to meet his family's needs and Minggas’ educational needs, such as his uniform and books. 

Frans usually works on the farm from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm. Frans faces challenges in farming. He has to fetch water from a well by using two buckets and then carrying them on his shoulders. Actually, there is a fresh water facility available in the village. It is provided by a Non-Government Institution in West Timor, but not all of the community members, including Frans, can access the fresh water facility because their houses are situated far from the main street. This is the reason why he has to fetch water from the well. Even though he has to walk for about four kilometers from his farm to fetch the water, Frans never complains. He is happy to do his work.

Frans and family live in a very simple house that is constructed of thatch (also called water reeds or roof reeds), It is called a ‘round house’ – this is a type of traditional house in the South Central Region of Timor). There is only one room available in this house for cooking and sleeping. Frans plans to build a better house for his family, but he cannot afford it as he is only a poor farmer. His income is only enough to meet their daily needs and his son’s educational needs. 

Frans heard from the clergyman in the village that the Kiva field partner, the Tanaoba Lais Manekat Foundation, provides cattle loans for farmers in West Timor through the Cattle Fattening Program. Many farmers have felt the benefits of this program. Frans discussed it with his neighbors and they decided to form a group of ten farmers to join the Cattle Fattening Program. The group was named Nasaret A1. He is interested in joining the program because he wants to build a house for his family. He believes that through this program he will be able to generate profits that can help him buy the necessary building materials. Frans is requesting a loan amounting to 3,400,000 IDR from TLM to buy young cattle to fatten in twelve months. The other group members are also requesting a loan to buy young cattle. They hope to have a better life through this loan.

Note: When the group picture was taken, Jermias was not present.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Srey Mom's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey Mom H. is the mother of four children.  Two are employed in different positions, while the others are attending the local school.  Her husband, Mr. Pol Sava, is a motorbike taxi driver who supports the family with his modest income. 

Mrs. Srey Mom H. is the leader of a group whose members all live in Preak Ta Ong village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land used for cultivating rice.  Her plantation faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizer to support the field. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is engaged in rice farming and a fish pond business. She has been managing her farm lots for almost twenty years, and her fishpond for almost five years. She would like to buy needed feed supplies for her fish pond, but her capital is not enough, so she hopes to borrow additional capital from the Kiva lenders amounting to 12,000 PHP.

Angelita is married to Manuel who helps manage their rice farm. They help each other to further develop and improve their businesses. Angelita hopes to obtain the amount she is requesting for her business improvement.

loans.use: to buy a supply of feed for her fishpond

loans.name: Rosamonda

texts.en:
Rosamonda manages a rice farm. The income from her one-hectare rice field is enough to supply the needs of her family. She is married to Rayven and they have two children, the eldest being 11 years old. She wants her children to have a better future, and to be provided with a proper education. She works hard in order to achieve it.

She joined the Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to request a loan that will be helpful in financing her business. She requested 10,000 PHP to purchase farm supplies for the maintenance of her farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 37 years old, married, and has two children. He has fifteen years of experience in this business and established his shop ten years ago. He has a good reputation in the market and, therefore, he has a lot of customers.

He wants to put more inventory in his shop with this loan in order to supply the needs of his customers and to increase his income.

loans.use: To develop his grocery shop

loans.name: Docas

texts.en:
Docas is married with three children and she is 30 years old. Her eldest child is 10 years old. Her husband is an electrician. All her children are excelling in school.

She fries and sells garri (cassava flakes) at retail and wholesale prices to her customers. Garri is gotten from cassava and it is a staple food in Nigeria. Docas lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for five years. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more cassava to fry as garri and then sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Ly O. leads a group of four people.  All four live in Prey Lieb village in Takeo province. Mrs. O. is a farmer who owns a plot of land, where she cultivates rice. She does not have enough money buy fertilizer for the rice field, so she is seeking a loan to buy the fertilizer. Mrs. Ly O. is widowed, and has a child who is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support a rice field.

loans.name: Senciaga

texts.en:
Senciaga B. is from the village of Balanlinao, Palridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Senciaga is married and has two school-age children.  She owns and operates a business venture selling food for snacks like "Puto" rice cakes and banana cue (deep-fried banana with caramelized brown sugar) in the local community. Senciaga has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Senciaga joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Senciaga is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials for food vending. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials for food vending

loans.name: Keut

texts.en: Keut Y., 53, is married with three children. She resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia with her husband and children. To make a living, she produces handcrafts made from brick, earning an income of approximately US $2 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of US $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Y. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate more income, so Y. is seeking a loan of US $600 to purchase additional brick so she can produce more handcrafts to sell.

loans.use: Buy more brick to produce handcrafts

loans.name: Nasaret A2 Group

texts.en:
Leon A. is a 41 year old man. He is a farmer who lives in Nenas Village, Fatumnasi Subdistrict, Kapan – in the South Central Region of Timor in East Nusa Tenggara Province. Leon is the leader of Nasaret A2 Group. The group consists of 10 farmers. Leon is married to Agatha Sila. They have four lovely children. They are: Arianto A., 17, who has dropped out of Junior High School since his parents were unable to finance his education. He often helps Leon in farming. Yusti A., 14, who is in the 6th Grade of Elementary School.  Sardiman A., 8, who is in Kindergarten. Sardiman was late to enter Kindergarten as Leon couldn’t afford it.  Nifron A., 5, is also in Kindergarten.

Leon has been working as a farmer since he was young. He is happy to be a farmer. He is grateful that he has his own fertile land that can be utilized as a farm. Leon plants carrots, corns, bananas, cassavas and king grass. He always tries to do the best that he can to fulfill his family's daily needs. Leon and the group members are lucky as they don’t have to sell their agricultural products at the market since the traders will come to buy directly from them.  

Leon is a keen farmer and usually works at the farm from 7 am to 4 pm. His wife and his son Arianto help him to water the plants and harvest the agricultural products. Fortunately, Leon has a well at the farm so he never faces difficulty in watering his plants.
  
Leon has dreams to renovate his house and finance his children’s education. He feels regret that he was unable to finance Arianto’s education. He does not want it happen to the rest of his children. 

Leon heard about TLM Cattle Fattening Program from the clergyman in the village. He is interested in joining the program so he can make his dreams come true. Together with his neighbors, they formed Nasaret A2 Group in order to get loans to buy young cattle to be fattened in twelve months. They hope that the loan will help them in improving their lives in the future.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Nasaret A3 Group

texts.en:
Nasaret A3 is a group of 10 farmers from Nenas Village, Fatumnasi Subdistrict, Kapan - in the South Central Region of Timor in East Nusa Tenggara Province. Nenas is situated about 74 km from the capital city of the South Central Region of Timor. Most of the community in Nenas supports their family life by farming.

Nasaret A3 Group is led by Martha N., a 35-year-old woman. Martha is married to a 54-year-old man who works as a teacher at an elementary school. Their marriage has been blessed with four children. They are: David P., 17, who is in Senior High School Grade 3; Daniman P., 14, who attends Junior High School Grade 3; Oma, 7, who is in Elementary School Grade 2; and Salomo, 5, who is not at school yet

Martha and her family live in a small house with two bedrooms. The kitchen was built separately from the main house – people in Timor usually call it a ‘round house’ (this is a type of traditional house in Timor). It is constructed with reeds, roof, and a dirt floor. Many of the community in the rural areas of the South Central Region of Timor have this type of traditional house. Generally, they use it as a kitchen and a place to sleep when the weather is cold. 

Martha usually starts her activities at 5 am. She looks after the children and prepares breakfast for them before they go to school. She also prepares  breakfast for her husband before he goes to work. After she completes her work at the house, Martha will go to the farm to cultivate her crops. She plants carrots, leeks and other vegetables. She usually spends about four hours at the farm. The challenge that Martha faces as a farmer is the availability of a water supply for her farm. The spring is situated about 2 km from the farm, so she has to walk that far to get the water. Her husband usually helps her in cultivating the farm after work. 

Living as a farmer with four children is not easy for Martha. Even though her husband is working as an elementary school teacher, the income generated is only enough to meet their daily needs. This is the reason why Martha is interested in joining the cattle fattening program. She wants to save money to send her son to study at the university. She also hopes to renovate her house. 

Martha and her group are requesting a loan to buy young cattle to fatten over a 12 month period.  All of them have the same dream, which is to have a better life.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites J. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 48 years old. Marites is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a  specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fish in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for more than 9 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for selling a variety of fish.

In 2009, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Marites is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan is the first that Marites has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and serves low-income households in Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Analou

texts.en:
28-year-old Analou is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has two kids and the oldest is sixteen years old.

Analou is into rice farming and has been doing it for quite some time now. Based on her experience, at times when she lacked finances, her harvest was small. So she joined CEVI in the hope of obtaining its financial services. She became a member in January and has been able to earn an income from her farm since.

Now Analou is requesting a loan of Php 9,000. She will use this loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs she needs at her farm. Hopefully, Analou’s yield could double at the next harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Mrs. Modesta F. owns a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field. She is 45 years old and married. She is now preparing her land for the planting season.

Modesta is a member of CEVI and she said that the impact brought by its financial services was positive. She is thankful its program was offered to farmers like her who are not able to accumulate capital on their own.

Now Modesta is applying for a loan of Php 9,000, which she will use to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Aurore

texts.fr: H. Aurore est née vers 1978 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Aurore vit à Dodomey à Allada depuis 30 ans environs. Divorcée et mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés, Aurore vit seule avec ses enfants. Aurore assure seule les charges de la famille. Aurore a fait seulement le cours primaire. Pour se prendre en charge et subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Aurore vend des condiments de sauce (tomate fraîche, piments, épices) au marché d’Allada au Bénin. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin et au marché Houègbo que Aurore s’approvisionne. Aurore a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. C’est pour augmenter le volume de son activité et faire face à la demande de la clientèle, que Aurore sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Aurore was born around 1978 in Allada in Atlantique county, Benin. She has been living in Dodomey, in Allada, for about thirty years. Divorced and the mother of two children, who are both in school, Aurore lives alone with her children. She alone ensures that family expenses are covered. Aurore has attended primary school only. To support herself and to provide for her children, she sells sauce condiments (fresh tomatoes, chili peppers, spices) at the Allada market in Benin. She stocks up in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and at the Houègbo market. She has already obtained an ALIDé loan, which she repaid. To increase her business volume and to cope with customer demand, she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 baskets of fresh tomatoes, 5 baskets of chili peppers, and various spices

loans.name: Adekunle

texts.en:
Adekunle sells planks at retail prices to his customers. He lives in Ogbomoso, Oyo State, Nigeria. He is 32 years old and is single without children. He hopes to get married very soon.

Adekunle has been in his business for a long time. He hopes to be a plank distributor in the future. He is requesting a loan of 130,000 NGN to purchase more planks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is excited to receive a Kiva loan. She is hoping for a loan of 100,000 NGN. She will use this loan to invest in a business selling provisions, which she will buy in bulk to get a better price. With this loan she will be able to build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family.

Patience is 32 years old, married, and has one child. She lives in warri, Delta state, Nigeria. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: Purchase more provisions

loans.name: Madelyn

texts.en:
Madelyn, 40 years old, is a farmer. She lives with her husband and their three children. Her oldest child is now 20. She does her best to keep her farm in good condition, and she is grateful that her last harvest was good. She is now preparing her land for the next planting, and she needs additional capital to run her farm.

Madelyn joined CEVI and applied for a loan of Php9000, which she would like to use to purchase farm necessities. This loan will help her immensely with the farm, and in turn, improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Mr. Leay Soun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people from Krang Thmei village in Kandal province are seeking this bank loan.  The borrowers will use their individual portions of the loan for different purposes. 

Mr. Leay S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where he cultivates rice. He is also vice village chief, and makes a small  salary to support his family.  His wife, Mrs. Vong Mao, helps him with the farming. Though they work hard, they would like to earn more income to improve their family's living conditions.  Mr. Leay S. is planning to use his portion of the loan to buy a cow for breeding, and he hopes to increase his income after he selling the cow.  

Mr. Leay S. is a father of two children:  One is a teacher and the other is a laborer. All of the members of this group are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: C1190 Twisungane Group

texts.en:
Felex is 35 years old and is married with three children aged 4, 8 and 12. He lives in Gicumbi in the Northern Province of Rwanda, a one-hour drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Felex is a hard working man and now he has become the president of a group called Twisungane.

The members of this group are well-known in their community and their restaurant business is a popular place for locals to hang out. This is their fourth successful year of operation! The hours of their restaurant require that they start early in the morning and work until late in the night every day of the week, oftentimes until the food runs out or the last customer is fed. They employ four people as helpers.

Felex and his group members have been in business since 2006 and they are ready to expand, but their operating profit is still too low for them to make some key purchases to enable the expansion. For this reason, they are requesting their first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders. With the loan, the group will be able to afford to buy modern cooking equipment and quality foods and supplies to satisfy their loyal customers. This effort will also help them to attract more customers as well as increase their monthly sales and profit.

With this profit, they all pledge to continue to reinvest in the business, pay school fees for their children, and build more secure futures for themselves and their families.

loans.use: To purchase modern cooking equipment and quality supplies

loans.name: Mousa

texts.en:
Mousa is a 29-year-old entrepreneur who is married with one child. He has a small computer repair shop.

He is requesting a loan of $3000 in order to purchase parts and tools needed for completing his jobs. It will inspire confidence in the service he provides, and most importantly customer satisfaction, which is of paramount importance to him.

loans.use: Purchase parts and tools

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 30 years old and is married. He has eighteen years of experience in this business and established his cafeteria twelve years ago. The cafeteria is in a good location in the city and hundreds of young people visit it to spend their time. Thus he gains a good income.

The purpose behind this loan is to expand his cafeteria in order to accomodate more customers and bring in a waiter as well.

loans.use: To purchase furniture and to improve the restaurant decor

loans.name: Clarisse

texts.fr: F. Clarisse est née en 1971 et est mariée à AMOUSSOUGA Cosme, un commerçant. Le couple a trois enfants, et un autre enfant à charge. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Clarisse vit à Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin, depuis 10 ans. C’est avec ses enfants et son mari que Clarisse vit. Clarisse a fait seulement le cours primaire. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Clarisse vend des divers (pâtes dentifrices, savons, papiers hygiéniques, piles, bougies, sachets, lait, tomates en boîtes, riz, huile végétale, etc.) au marché d’Allada. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin que Clarisse s’approvisionne. Clarisse est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’accroître son activité et d’augmenter davantage son chiffre d’affaire, Clarisse sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
F. Clarisse was born on 1971 and is married to AMOUSSOUGA Cosme, a merchant. The couple has three children plus another child to support. Some of them are in school. Clarisse has been living in Dogoudo, in Allada (Atlantique county, in Benin) for ten years. She lives with her children and husband. Clarisse has attended primary school only. For twelve years, she has been selling a variety of goods (toothpaste, soaps, toilet paper, batteries, candles, baggies, milk, canned tomatoes, rice, vegetable oil, etc.) at the Allada market. She stocks up in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a previous ALIDé client having already had two ALIDé loans, which were repaid. With the aim of growing her business and increasing her sales, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods (boxes of soap and canned foods, sacks of rice)

loans.name: Janita

texts.en:
Janita is a 49-year-old married woman. She has six children and the oldest is now twenty-two years old.

As a rice farmer, Janita had to learn how to keep the farm healthy and free of weeds. She also consults her farmer friends about farming techniques.

In need of additional capital, Janita applied to Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to gain access to its financial services. She is requested a loan of Php 7,000 to be used for fertilizers and other farming necessities. This loan will surely be helpful to Janita’s farming.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Elsita

texts.en:
Elsita L. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 52 years old. Elsita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Elsita makes and sells homemade food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snack food in the local community. Elsita has been engaged in her business for more than 40 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Elsita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first taken out by Elsita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and serves the low-income households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: 36-year-old Janet B. is a rice farmer. She is married and lives in Agusan Del Sur. She harvested her crops and is now preparing the land for planting. She joined CEVI to gain access to financial service that could support her farm. She also wants to improve her family’s living conditions. She asked for a loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos. This loan will be used to buy seed, fertilizer, and other items needed at her farm. This loan will truly be helpful in Janet’s journey to a better life.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Rodelia

texts.en: Rodelia is a married woman. She is 39 years old and has two children. Her oldest child is 22 years old. Residing in Agusan Del Sur, she invested in rice farming, which is one of the main livelihoods there. She says she needs financial support for her farm. She hired some laborers who are already preparing her land for planting. She applied to Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asked for a loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos. She will use this loan to buy seed, fertilizer, and other supplies, and also to pay for the laborers.

loans.use: Farm supplies and payroll

loans.name: Mrs. Chatha Nat Village Bank Group

texts.en:
A village bank loan which consists of nineteen people is located in Pou Thum village in Kandal province.  All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chatha N. is the village bank president. She is a grocer who owns a small grocery store in the local village.

Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more general products to resell to earn more income and improve her business. Her husband, Mr. Hoem Sokha, helps her with the business. Mrs. Chatha N. is 31 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy general products to resell to earn more income and improve her business.

loans.name: Rang

texts.en: Rang L., 20, is married with a young child. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and child. To make a living, she and her husband produce traditional Cambodian drums for tourists, collectively earning an income of US $7 per day. Her husband always helps his wife in the business. L. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, L. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase a new motorbike to use for transporting materials to produce drums.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita has been married to her husband Wilfredo for 33 years. They are blessed with five children. The oldest among her kids is now 28 years old. Lolita is a rice farmer. She enjoys working at her farm and keeping it in good condition, for it is her main source of income. She wants to earn more so she can help improve her family’s living conditions.

Lolita is a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She requested a loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos. With this loan, she will buy seed and fertilizer, and will also pay the laborers who helped at her farm. This loan will be helpful to Lolita and her family.

loans.use: Farm supplies and payroll

loans.name: Geraldin

texts.en:
Geraldin L. is from the village of Naasag, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old and single. To make a living, Geraldin owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Geraldin has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Geraldin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Geraldin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Geraldin is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Geraldin from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rosebel

texts.en: Rosebel is a 29-year-old rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She is married and has six kids. Her oldest child is only twelve. She aims to improve her family’s living conditions. Rosebel is now preparing her farm for planting. She will need seed, fertilizer, and other farming supplies. Unable to finance her farm, she sought the help of CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines and also a KIVA partner. She applied for a loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos, which she will use to finance her farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies and payroll

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: Rice Farming is Gemma’s way of living. She is 40 years old, married, and has four children. Her oldest child is only 14. Gemma works hard to provide for her family. She takes extra care of her farm because it is where she gets her income. She is now preparing her land for planting. She applied to CEVI and asked for a loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos. She will use this loan for seed, fertilizer, and other farming necessities. Hopefully, her farm's yield could double on the next harvest.

loans.use: Seed, fertilizer, and other farm supplies

loans.name: 02.08.1.6 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Linh T. Thị (30) is a 41 year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá . Linh is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02.08.1.6 Nam Ngạn (02.08.1.6 Nam Ngạn).

Linh is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To making a living, Linh owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling rice products in the local community. Linh has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, Linh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Linh has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,963,500 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. The loan will be the third loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Linh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1. Ngô Thị Hoa (31) is a 22 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

2. H. Thị Hường (32) is a 44 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.

3. N. Thị Mai (33) is a 50 year-old female who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Linh T. Thị (30) là 41 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá . Linh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.08.1.6 Nam Ngạn (02.08.1.6 Nam Ngạn).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương. Linh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Linh kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND. Vào 2008, Linh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Linh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.963.500 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các thành phần thô cần thiết để chế tạo sản phẩm để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. Ngô Thị Hoa (31) là 22 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

2. H. Thị Hường (32) là 44 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

3. N. Thị Mai (33) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Thach Pen Village Bank Group

texts.en: A village bank loan consists of nineteen people who all live in Pou Thum village in Kandal province. Mrs. Thach P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who grows bananas. She now faces a small problem in this business because she does not have enough money to support the banana tree, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Tes S., helps her with the farming. Mrs. Thach P. is 52 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are laborers.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers

loans.name: Percinita

texts.en:
Percinita enjoys taking care of her farm. She is 54 years old and has been married for 36 years now. She has 5 children with her husband Ernesto. Like any other mother, she wants to have a happy home and hopes to improve her family’s living condition.

Percinita joined CEVI in order to benefit from its financial services. She joined in January and is grateful that she gained access to its program. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 9,000. The money will be used to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: purchasing farm supplies

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: Y. Madeleine est née le 26 Juin 1982 à Abomey, ville historique du Bénin. Madeleine est mariée à LINKPONDJI Janvier, un guérisseur traditionnel. Le couple a un enfant qui est scolarisé. Madeleine vit seul avec son enfant à Dogoudo à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin, depuis 5 ans. C’est Madeleine seule qui supporte les charges de la famille. Madeleine n’a fait que le cours primaire. Il y a quatre ans de cela que Madeleine vend des condiments de sauce (piment, oignons, sels, cube, allumettes, etc.) et également des sandalettes au marché d’Allada. Madeleine s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et aussi à Allada. Madeleine a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. En vue d’accroître son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, Madeleine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Y. Madeleine was born on June 26, 1982 in Abomey, a historic village of Benin. She is married to LINKPONDJI Janvier, a traditional healer. The couple has one child who is in school. Madeleine has been living alone with her child in Dogoudo, in Allada (Atlantique county, in Benin) for five years. She alone supports the family. Madeleine has attended primary school only. For four years, she has been selling sauce condiments (chili peppers, onions, salt, bouillon cubes, matches, etc.) and also sandalettes (flip-flops) at the Allada market. She stocks up on supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and also in Allada. She has already benefited from one ALIDé loan, which she repaid. With the aim of growing her business and boosting her sales, she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sauce condiments (sacks of chili peppers and onions), 10 sacks of table salt

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita, 50 years old, occupies herself with farming. She cultivates rice. She helps her husband Diosdado maintain their farm. She keeps an eye out for weeds and immediately stops them from growing. She joined CEVI in order to gain access to its financial services. She is now requesting a loan of PHP 7,000. She will use this money to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other supplies needed at her farm. This loan will help Teresita improve and expand her farm.

loans.use: purchasing seeds, fertilizer and other supplies needed at her farm

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a rice farmer. She is 47 years old, married and has seven kids. Her oldest child is now 25 years old. She does her best to keep her farm in good shape. She aims to produce quality rice that she can both sell and use to feed her family.

Grace joined CEVI in January 2009 and is thankful for the financial services to which she has gained access. She is currently requesting for a loan of PHP 9,000. With this loan, Grace will be able to buy seeds, fertilizer and other supplies that she needs for her farm.

loans.use: purchasing seeds, fertilizer and other supplies needed at her farm

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy C., 33, is married with four school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in the business of selling groceries in her village, earning an income of US $5 per day. Her husband always helps her with the business. He also sells pork at a local market, earning an approximate income of US $7 per day. C. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, C. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase 10 pigs for resale.

loans.use: To buy 10 pigs

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing, 40 years old, is married with 2 children. She is very hardworking. Specifically, she sells cooked foods. She has been in this business all of her life and consequently has the experience of ensuring that she keeps her customers coming back by giving them the best dish possible. With the profit she makes, she assists her family. She is requesting a loan of N 100,000; she will use the money to purchase more foodstuffs. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: purchasing more foodstuffs

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is a 40 year old married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She lives with her husband and their five children. Her oldest child is now 18. She works hard not merely to provide for the daily needs of her family, but also to save for her children’s future. Evelyn is currently preparing her land for planting. She needs seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies. She thus applied to CEVI and is now requesting a loan of PHP 7,000. She will use this loan to finance her farm, buy the necessary supplies and pay the laborers who work at her farm.

loans.use: purchasing seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is a 45-year-old widow with three children between the ages of 6 and 20.  All of her children go to school. Annet rents a one-room house where she stays with four people.  Annet also takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity or piped water, but does get three meals a day.   

Annet works seven days a week in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala, where she has a pub in the Lubaga Road Kitawuluzi zone and sells all types of beer.  She also sells food. She receives an average of 50 customers a day and sells both retail and wholesale. She incurs transport costs from buying crates of beer from Kampala city.

Annet has been in this business for more than 5 years. Her major business challenge is  the ever-increasing price of food and beer. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and bunches of bananas. Annet aspires to own a beer depot.	

Annet has been with MCDT for five years, and is servicing her tenth loan. Annet joined MCDT because of its location near her home and its convenience.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and  bunches of bananas

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en: Merlita M. is a 41-year-old married woman who lives in Purok Paraiso, Baranggay 2, Taloc, Bago City, Negros Occidental. Her husband, Emmanuel, is a small sugar farmer. They have three young children who are between 4 and 9 years old. The older kids are presently attending elementary school. Merlita works hard to help her husband provide for their children’s future because she does not want them to go through the same hardships she had while she was growing: needing to have a paying job just to help her parents support their family. Her most cherished dream is for her children to finish their studies and get a stable job or have an established livelihood. Merlita met her husband in Manila many years ago when she worked as a factory worker just to help her parents support their family. When they got married, they decided to go home to Negros where Emmanuel had a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farmland that he could plant with sugarcane. Merlita had to adjust to living in a new place and she also realized that she needed to have her own source of income so that she could help her husband support their family. When Merlita gave birth to their oldest child, she decided to put up a general store adjacent to their house. She thought that this would serve two purposes: she could take care of her child and their household while selling basic goods to her neighbors and earn a supplemental income for their family. But in spite of her best efforts, she could not sustain the required inventory level that was needed and she sometimes did not have enough stock to sell. She almost decided to close down her store. It was serendipity that a friend introduced Merlita to NWTF-Project Dungganon, and when she became a member in 2002, she was able to access the much-needed capital to support the capital requirements of her store. She was even able to expand her product offerings. As her business grew, Merlita started selling rice to her neighbors, and also raised pigs in her backyard. Now she earns a minimum of PHP 10,000 per month from her business activities. She is currently saving money for the education of her children and also so that she can buy a motorcycle which they will use as another source of income. Merlita’s previous loan of PHP 22,500 was utilized as revolving working capital for her businesses. Having paid that in due course, Merlita is borrowing PHP 25,000 this time around so that she can continue sustaining the capital requirements of her businesses. She hopes that all her efforts will bear fruit in the fulfillment of all her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: 42-year-old Elena tills her farm with patience. She prepares her land for rice crops. As a basic necessity for Filipinos, she wants her rice to be of quality. She feels her service is good when she sells the best rice. In need of financial assistance for her farm, she applied to CEVI and asked for a loan of PHP7,000. This loan will be used for farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. Receiving this loan will be truly helpful in achieving Elena’s goal.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
64-year-old Ramon tills his farm with patience and diligence. He has been married to his wife Rena for 43 years. They are blessed with nine children. The oldest, who is now 39 years old, is already married and does not live with them anymore. Like any other father, he wants the best for his children. He works hard to improve his family’s living condition.

Ramon joined CEVI in January 2009. Now he is requesting a loan of PHP6,000, which will be used for farm inputs. This loan is a big help to Ramon’s farming and in achieving his goal to improve his family’s living condition.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Adeline

texts.en: Adeline is married with four children. She is 50 years old. Her husband is a businessman. She sells medicines, drinks and plastics in Ogbomoso, Oyo state, Nigeria. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic necessities of her immediate family members. She has been in this business for a long time. Adeline is requesting a loan of 50,000 Nigeria naira (NGN) to purchase more medicine and plastics to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and plastics to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria has been married to her husband Ronie for 24 years now. She is 40 years old and takes care of her eight children. The oldest of her kids is now 23. She invested in rice farming. She is more than happy to share that her last harvest was good. She hopes to double up her harvest this time.

As a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., she applied for a loan of PHP9,000. She will use this loan to buy farm inputs such as seeds, fertilizers and other items that will help her achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Heng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This loan is being requested by a group of 15 people who live in Rumchek village in Takeo province.  Mrs. Sam H., a silk weaver,  was selected as village bank president by the members of the group.  This business is going well, so she would like to buy more silk to weave for her customers.  She plans to use her portion of the loan to buy more silk. 

Her husband, Mr. Tun Saor, is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field where he cultivates rice for a living. Mrs. Sam H. is 52 years old and the mother of two children.  One of her children is a driver and makes a small salary that helps support the family.  The youngest child attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave for her customers.

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem K., 30, is married with two school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband (pictured) and children. To make a living, she runs a hair dressing shop in her village, earning about US $2.50 per day. Her husband helps her with her business.  He also produces palm sugar, earning approximately US $8 per day. K. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. K. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike to transport palm trees and other materials to produce traditional handcrafts as souvenirs for tourists.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Arvin

texts.en:
Arvin D. is from the village of Poblacion, Catarman Camiguin Province. He is 31 years old. Arvin is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Arvin makes and sells food.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from peddling specialty food products like "chicharon," a dish made from fried pork rinds, in the local community. Arvin has been engaged in his business for more than 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Arvin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. Arvin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000  PHP  from HSPFI.  Arvin is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the fourth loan that Arvin has taken out from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve and expand his business.. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and serves the low-income households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina is 47 years old and married with two children. Her husband is an agriculturist. She sells cosmetics and kitchen utensils. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family members. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. Augustina is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en: Mary Jean is a young mother. At 18, she now has a 7-month-old baby with her husband, and has learned farming to help support her family. She plants rice because it is a necessity among Filipinos and she can sell it easily. New to married life, she wants to build a happy home, and gives her all to farming because it is a source of income. She has also joined CEVI to take advantage of financial services that can help her expand her farm. She has applied for a loan of PHP 9,000, which she will use to buy equipment for her farm.

loans.use: to buy farm equipment

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en: Genevieve is 30 years old and owns a rice farm. She manages this farm very carefully because it is the source of her income. She needs to buy equipment, and has turned to CEVI, a microfinance institution in the Philippines, for a loan of PHP 9,000. Genevieve will will use this loan to upgrade her farm, produce an abundant harvest, and increase her income.

loans.use: to upgrade her farm

loans.name: Mrs. Sary Muon Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people in Rumchek village in Takeo province have joined together to request a group loan. All of the members will use their portion of the  loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sary M. was selected as village bank president  by the members. She is a silk weaver in the village, and has many customers. Mrs. Sary M. is seeking a loan to buy more silk to weave, to meet her customers' demand. Mrs. Sary M. is 47 years old and has four children.  One of her children is a teacher, the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more silk to weave

loans.name: Airene

texts.en: Mrs. Airene P. has three children with her husband Acquim. She is 30 years old and has worked her farm for many years. She is grateful that she owns a one-hectare field because she does not have to work on other people’s farms, like many of her neighbors do. Airene joined CEVI to help improve her farm and has applied for a PHP 9,000 loan, which she will use to buy new equipment and pay the people who work for her.

loans.use: to help improve a rice farm

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en: Ramon is 38 years old and a very experienced farmer. He does not have many resources, but makes up for that by working especially hard, and has kept his farm in good condition so that it produces a quality crop. He has applied to CEVI for a PHP 9,000 loan to buy fertilizers and other supplies. He is very grateful to have CEVI and Kiva as a source of financial assistance because this loan can make a huge difference on his farm.

loans.use: to help improve a rice farm

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en: Brenda is a 26-year-old mother of two and has been married to her husband Roderick for two years. Her oldest child is seven. Brenda has invested in rice farming to help sustain her family. She works hard to keep her farm in good condition while also taking care of her family. She is a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and applied for a loan of PHP 9,000 to buy fertilizer and other supplies for her farm.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her farm

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en: Adelaida D. is from the village of San Jose, Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old. Adelaida is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Adelaida owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2008, Adelaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Adelaida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Hélène

texts.fr: D. Hélène est née en 1968 à Dassa-Zoumé dans les collines au Bénin. Mariée à HOUNSOUVO Galbert, un enseignant, Hélène est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge. C’est depuis deux ans que Hélène vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Dogoudo à Allada. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour répondre à ses besoins, Hélène vend du maïs, des bananes et de la farine de manioc à Allada. Hélène s’approvisionne à Allada et au marché Houègbo au Bénin. C’est depuis 16 ans que Hélène mène cette activité. Hélène a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’augmenter le volume de son activité et de faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Hélène sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Hélène was born in 1968 in Dassa-Zoumé in the hills of Benin. Married to HOUNSOUVO Galbert, a teacher, she is the mother of three children who are all in school. The couple has another child to support. For two years, she has been living with her children and husband in Dogoudo, in Allada. The couple provides for the family jointly. To meet her needs, Hélène sells corn, bananas, and cassava flour in Allada. She stocks up in Allada and at the Houègbo market in Benin. She has been in this business for sixteen years. She has already had two ALIDé loans, which have been repaid. With the aim of increasing her business volume and to cope with the demands of her customers, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy six tubs of cassava flour and some plantains

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a young man of 27 and he is married with three kids. He has a small business in the streets of the city of Gaza in Palestine where he sells products such as perfumes, creams and clothes.

Ali wants to increase his merchandise and to offer a wider variety of products to his clients since at this time his products are in high demand. In order to do so,he is requesting a loan of $3000. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To increase his merchandise

loans.name: Yarv

texts.en:
Yarv C. is 24 years old and lives with her husband in Takeo province. She makes and sells food at the local resort in front of the riverside. On average, she is able to make about US $3 per day. Her husband is a fisherman and makes US $2 each day. This couple has three young children.

Yarv C. is asking for a loan of US $600 to build a stand along the riverside so that she can welcome guests to sit and buy her food.

loans.use: Build a stand.

loans.name: Lucky

texts.en: Lucky sells cooked food in front of her house; she is single, and a very hard-working lady. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She plans to expand her restaurant business, if there are enough funds.  To do this she is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more food and drinks . She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: Ingredients for food production

loans.name: 02.03.1.5 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Hoa P. Thị (24) is a 31 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Hoa is the group leader of a 4 member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 03.1.5 Nam Ngạn (02.03.1.5). Hoa is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, Hoa owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling baked goods in the local community. Hoa has been engaged in this business for over 9 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities. In 2007, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hoa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,442,600 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hoa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. N. Thị Đỡ (23) is a 59 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her livestock raising business. 2. N. Thị Tố Hảo (25) is a 59 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her general store. 3. Lê Thị Chuật (26) is a 42 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Hoa P. Thị (24) là 31 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá. Hoa là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.
