Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 03.1.5 (02.03.1.5). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm nung trong cộng đồng địa phương. Hoa thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 9 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Hoa kiếm được khoảng 3000000 VND. Vào 2007, Hoa đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Hoa đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.442.600 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các thành phần thô cần thiết để chế tạo sản phẩm để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. N. Thị Đỡ (23) là 59 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. N. Thị Tố Hảo (25) là 59 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa. 3. Lê Thị Chuật (26) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy T.i đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất T.n kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 34 years old and married with four children between the ages of 3 and 17. All her children go to school. She resides in a five roomed house she owns and lives with seven people. Eva takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Eva works in a semi urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She incurs transport costs to and from buying used clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city. She works six days a week. She receives an average of five customers a day and sells to all categories of people in both retail and wholesale. She has a shop where she sells second hand clothes in Lungujja Kitunzi zone, and sells all types of of second hand clothes. Besides selling second hand clothes, she’s also a tailor, sewing ladies clothes. Her major business challenge is the ever increasing price of second hand clothes. Eva has been with MCDT for five years and is servicing her tenth loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothes for the festive season. She aspires to sell wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas T., 53, is a widow and lives with seven children in the Takeo province. Since 2005, she has been selling grocery items and planting vegetables to earn a living and is able to make US$2 of profit every day. She is aided by four of the children who are garment factory workers. Meas T. is asking for a loan of US$800, which she needs to expand her grocery inventory.

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly S. is 39 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make about US$2 of profit every day, while her husband is a construction worker who builds houses. He typically makes US$3 a day. This couple has six children and all of them are in school. Ly S. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase silk clothes to sell at the local market.

loans.use: To purchase silk clothes to sell

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Chhem N. is 39 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make about US$2 of profit every day, while her husband, pictured here, is a construction worker who builds houses. He typically makes US$3 a day. This couple has six children and all of them are in school. Chhem N. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase silk clothes to sell at the local market.

loans.use: To purchase silk clothes to sell

loans.name: Ham

texts.en: Ham S., 31, is a widow who lives with three children in the Takeo province. She is a professional weaver and is able to make US$2 of profit every day. Three of her children are in school. Ham S. would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to purchase silk clothes to sell at the local market.

loans.use: To purchase silk clothes to sell

loans.name: Badegna (Fraternité) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit  femmes du groupe Badegna, composé de 6 mariées, une veuve et une célibataire, ont en moyenne  36 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles polygames traditionnelles à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers de la ville de la préfecture de Koutiala, région de Sikasso. 
Elles sont unies par des liens de voisinage, de parenté et professionnels. 
L’activité dominante de ces femmes est l’achat vente de tissus accompagné de celui des produits cosmétiques et de la fabrication du savon traditionnel.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle, le groupe Badegna a rapproché l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son  premier  prêt solidaire. 
Le prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 pièces de tissus, des paquets de produits cosmétiques et quelques fûts en matière première pour la fabrication du savon. 
La connaissance du milieu a permis aux femmes du groupe de savoir le goût de sa clientèle. C’est pour cela que leur produit est sollicité dans la ville de Koutiala et elles ont de l’expérience dans leur secteur d’activité. La vente du produit est faite de trois manières à savoir sur place à la maison, au marché et en ambulant dans les  quartiers de la ville  de Koutiala.  
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 22 815CFA chacune par mois. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser  le prêt et son intérêt, contribuer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et participer à la prise en charge des frais de scolarité des enfants. 
Les membres du groupe Badegna ont pour ambition, l’élargissement de leur domaine d’activité en associant d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
The eight women in the Badegna ('brotherhood') group, composed of 6 married women, one widow, and one single woman, have an average age of 36 and 2 children, on average. They all live in traditional polygamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods of the town of the prefecture of Koutiala, Sikasso region. They are united by ties of neighborhood or kinship, and by professional bonds.

The main activity of these women is buying and selling cloth and cosmetics, and making traditional soap. Wishing to satisfy their clientele, the Badegna group came to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their first solidarity loan. .

The loan will be used to buy 20 lengths of cloth, packages of cosmetic products, and some barrels of raw materials for making soap.

Familiarity with their milieu has permitted the women of this group to understand the tastes of their clientele. For that reason, their products are sought after in the town of Koutiala, and they have experience in their sector and activities. They make their sales in three different ways: out of their homes, at the market, and on foot, walking around the town of Koutiala.

With this loan, they expect to make an average monthly profit of 22,815 F CFA each. This profit will be used to reimburse the loan and the interest, to contribute to the daily family expenses, and help pay the school fees for their children. Their ambition is to expand their businesses by adding on other money-earning activities.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim S., 45, is married with three young children living at home in the Takeo province. 

She works in a grocery store, typically making $8 USD each day. Her husband stays at home and helps her. Kim S. would like a loan of $1,000 USD to expand her grocery inventory.

loans.use: To expand her grocery inventory.

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty is a fashion designer; she is 35, married, and has two children. She wishes to expand her business by adding the sale of tailoring materials and sarongs; she believes that having an assortment of sarongs that are of good quality will increase her sales. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Yiriwa (Épanouissement) Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Yiriwa sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala (région de Sikasso). 
Les membres du groupe vivent dans des familles polygames et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et professionnel. 
Elles exercent différentes activités à savoir la vente de sounbala, de savons, de condiments alimentaires, du bois de chauffe et des tasses en plastique. 
Dans le but de satisfaire sa clientèle, le groupe Yiriwa a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Ce groupe est son quatrième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) dont les trois premiers ont été très bien remboursé. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, une importante quantité de sounbala, des paquets produits cosmétiques, des chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe. 
Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des producteurs  des villages environnants et  des commerçants grossistes de Koutiala. Elles effectuent leurs ventes en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile,  au grand marché de Koutiala. 
Pour leur sérieux dans le travail, les membres du groupe Yiriwa sont très sollicités dans le quartier  pour la qualité de leurs produits.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 35000CFA chacune par mois. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser  le prêt et son intérêt, contribuer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et participer à la prise en charge des frais de scolarité des enfants.
texts.en:
The six women composing Yiriwa (blossoming) Group are all married and, on average, are 39 years old and have four children. They live all in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye in the prefecture of Koutiala (region of Sikasso). They live in polygamous families and know each other through family, neighborhood or professional links.

They run various businesses, namely selling sounbala (a condiment which is traditionally much prized in Mali and West Africa), soap, food condiments, firewood and plastic cups. To meet the demand from their customers, the members of Yiriwa Group came to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and applied for their fourth solidarity loan (group loan). They have repaid without any problem their first three loans.

They will use this new loan to buy a large quantity of sounbala, boxes of cosmetics and cartloads of firewood. They get their supplies from the producers in the nearby villages and from wholesalers in Koutiala. They retail their products for cash and credit, both from their homes and at the great market in Koutiala. The members of Yiriwa Group are very much in demand in their neighborhood because customers appreciate their reliability and the quality of their products.

Thanks to this loan, they expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 CFA francs each. They will use their profit to pay the installments of this loan, contribute to the daily expenses of their families and participate in the payment of the school fees for their children.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various articles

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This entrepreneur is 25 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is employed and earns $450.  Three years ago he opened his own shop to increase his income; he has five years experience in this area.  He wants this loan to enlarge his shop to get more customers. He has a good reputation in the market.

loans.use: To buy stoves and freezer

loans.name: Omogbe

texts.en: Paulina is 35 years old, married, and has 3 children.  She sells food. She is a focused, hard-working woman. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. She is happy with her business and assists her husband with the profit from the business. She wishes to expand her business in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more food to sell. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Djiguiya (Recours) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya du quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala est  composé de quatre  femmes dont trois  mariées et une veuve avec une moyenne de 48 ans et 3 enfants. Les membres du groupe Djiguiya vivent dans des familles polygames et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et professionnel. 
L’activité dominante des femmes de ce groupe est l’achat vente de sounbala, des produits cosmétiques et des condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt,  le groupe Djiguiya est à son  deuxième prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 sacs de noix de soja ou du néré, de la matière première pour la fabrication des produits cosmétiques et de diverses marchandises pour la vente en détail. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des producteurs et grossistes de Koutiala. La vente des produits est faite sur place à la maison, au marché et en ambulant dans  les  quartiers de la ville  de Koutiala.  
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25000CFA chacune par mois. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser  le prêt et son intérêt, contribuer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et participer à la prise en charge des frais de scolarité des enfants. 
Les membres du groupe Djiguiya  envisagent  s’installer au grand marché de Koutiala au nom de l’association.
texts.en:
The Djiguiya group of the Hamdallaye district of the prefecture of Koutiala is composed of four women, three married women and one widow, with an average age of 48 and on average 3 children. The members of the Djiguiya group live in polygamous families and know each other through ties of kinship, or because they live in the same neighborhood, or through their businesses.

The main business of these women is buying and selling 'sounbala' (a condiment), cosmetics, and other condiments. After having reimbursed their first loan, the Djiguiya group are on their second solidarity loan with Soro Yiriwaso.

This loan will be used to buy 20 sacks of soy nuts or 'néré', raw materials for making cosmetic products, and various merchandise to be sold retail. They do their buying from the producers and wholesalers of Koutiala. Sales are made out of their homes, at the market, or on foot in the neighborhoods of the town of Koutiala.

With this loan, they expect to make an average profit of 25,000 CFA each every month. This profit will be used to reimburse the loan and the interest, to contribute to covering everyday family expenses, and to participate in paying school fees for their children. The members of the Djiguiya group hope to be able to set themselves up in the big open-air market of Koutiala as an association.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles

loans.name: Avazjon

texts.en:
A. Avazjon is originally from the region of Spitamen and for several years has dedicated himself to cattle breeding. He has attended to this work with great effort in order to maintain his home. Avazjon is married with two little children and has the duty of supporting his family. For this reason he has decided to come to IMON International for help in buying young cattle. It is his dream to develop his business with more loans and in this way continue to maintain his humble home. Avazjon promises to repay this loan in a timely manner and thanks all KIVA lenders for trusting and supporting him. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase more cattle

loans.name: Lorlina

texts.en:
Lorlina is a 46 year-old widow with five children, four of whom are already working and helping out with the household expenses, while the youngest still attends school. Lorlina has a live-in partner named Marcial who also helps her in her business. They live in Brgy. Libacao, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental.

Lorlina and Marcial have a simple dream – for her youngest child to finish college, have electricity connected to their house, buy their own incubator for their balut business (balut is fertilized duck egg with a nearly developed embryo that is boiled and eaten in the shell), and be able to buy a tricycle (a motorcycle with side car) to deliver their products. If she accomplishes these goals, she knows that their living conditions will surely improve.

Even before she started her business, she thought of what to do to help improve and make life easy for her family. She decided that selling street food like boiled peanut and balut. They developed a daily routine of buying raw balut and peanuts in the morning and cooking fresh batches daily and going around the town streets to sell their products. It was hard work but it earned a living for their family, so Lorlina persevered.

In 2004, Lorlina saw the opportunity to expand her business and joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access the capital necessary to increase her sales volume. This turned out to be a good decision and she was finally able to set up a permanent place to display her products.  Now instead of operating a roving business, she can let her customers come to her in the same place every day. 

Lorlina earns a net profit of about 10,000 Philippine pesos (about $213 US) or sometimes more per month. At present, she is setting aside a portion for her “motorcycle fund” and for the education of her youngest child.  Her previous loan of 15,000 pesos was used as revolving capital for her balut and peanut business. 

Now she is borrowing, for her 11th loan cycle, the amount of 18,000 pesos.  This loan will be used both as revolving working capital for her balut and peanut business and to buy piglets to raise and sell for a profit when they are fully grown. Some part of the income from this will be added to her motorcycle fund until she could buy her dream motorcycle for her deliveries, and the rest will be for the education and support of their family. 

When she has bought her motorcycle, Lorlina intends to start saving up for her incubator so that she can make the balut herself and increase her profit margin.

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her food stall business and new pig fattening business

loans.name: Burkhon

texts.en: A. Burkhon is a 49-year-old man who is married with two children. He is an experienced livestock breeder in the village of Djabbar Rasulov, Tajikistan. His main source of income is farming and raising livestock. In order to better manage his herds and increase his productivity, Burkhon needs to build an enclosure for them and to purchase mangers, etc. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of 800 USD. This will allow him to make his livestock business more profitable so that he can better support his family. loans.use: To build an enclosure for his cattle and to purchase mangers

loans.name: Lcy

texts.en:
Lcy is very hardworking and she makes sure she has food on the table everyday through her hard work. She is 48 years old and is married with eight children. She lives in Warri, Delta State.

Lcy sells household items in front of her house and has been in this business for years. She has the mind to expand her business and business capital but the challenge she is facing is funding. She is requesting the loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more household items to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more household items to sell

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
K. Rustam is a very active 44-year-old man. He's married and has one child. Seventeen years ago, he started a business raising cattle, which he usually sells to local restaurants. This is his primary and stable business. During harvest season, Rustam also earns additional income as a farmer. Because both of his businesses are still quite small, they don't generate enough income for the whole family.

Rustam would like to request a loan to expand his businesses and increase his family income. He will use the profit generated by the businesses to repay the loan on time. With this purpose in mind, he is asking for a loan of $800 USD in order to buy and raise more cattle to sell. The well-being of his family and his businesses are in your hands. Rustam is sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.use: Purchase additional cattle

loans.name: Khursanoy

texts.en: Khursanoy is a native of Spitamen, Tajikistan, and has stayed in her native land to progress there. That is why, five years ago, she decided to move forward with raising livestock. She began with just one cow and now has many. Every morning, she goes out early so that her beloved cows may graze among the hills all day in hopes that they return happy and satisfied. Khursanoy is motivated to continue in this arduous work by the thought of her four children who, along with her husband, also help her with the cows. In order to succeed in her business, she and her family look to nourish the animals and keep them happy, in hopes of ultimately selling them at a good price. Thanks to her continued activity in her occupation, Khursanoy and her family are able to sustain themselves and this fills her with great satisfaction. However, with the support of this loan, Khursanoy would now like to also purchase more species of livestock to increase her clientele. With your support, she will be able to accomplish her business goals, thus helping to fund the education of all four of her children. loans.use: To purchase calves to expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This enterpreneur is 23 years old and single. He has 8 years of experience in this business. He established his own shop 6 years ago and has one waiter. Because there are a lot of demands on his work, wants to buy more clay ovens and hire another waiter. He hopes to improve his living standards.

loans.use: To buy flour and clay ovens and hire another employee

loans.name: Dadajon

texts.en:
N. Dadajon is a 35-year-old married man who lives with his three children and owns a small farm. He lives and works in a small village in the Northern part of Tajikistan in Djabbar Rasulov region. Dadajon, together with his wife (pictured), have been running a business raising and selling cattle. He has 11 years of experience in this field. Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Dadajon has become a very successful businessman in a very short period. The income is enough to cover family needs but as his children grow, covering family needs has become harder. So Dadajon applied for a loan to expand his activities and to purchase more cattle. With your help, Dadajon can get ahead.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This entrepreneur is 29 years old and single. He has 8 years of experience in his business and has one employee. This is the second loan that he has received from Al-Thiqa to enlarge his shop. He plans to use this loan to expand his shop and hire more employees to raise his income.

loans.use: To buy equipment and decorations for his barber shop

loans.name: Hadiza

texts.en: Hadiza is married with four children. She is 33 years old. She sells drinks in front of her house. She is a very hard working woman. With her profits, she helps her family. She wishes to increase her stock during this season but her greatest challenge is funding. If she is given a loan of 100,000 she will be able to purchase drinks directly from the company van. She believes she will get a better price from the company. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell
